Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Jaunt Coffee Roasters is a San Diego-based roaster and café with an extensive coffee and food menu. Visit

Coffee Name: Panama Renaissance Series Flora Geisha Washed
Blind Assessment: Floral-toned, sweetly herbaceous. Narcissus, rosemary, cocoa nib, amber, honey in aroma and cup. Bright, balanced acidity; Delicate, silky-smooth mouthfeel. Very long, resonant, flavor-laden finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). CoffeeBox Coffee founders Godfrey and Coco focus on small-batch coffee roasting with the goal of making the joy of premium coffee accessible to everyone. Visit

Blind Assessment: Sweet, richly spice-toned. Cinnamon, clove, baking chocolate, fig bar, amber in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of baking chocolate and cinnamon.
Notes: Produced by Luis Eduardo Campos of Cordillera del Fuego, from trees of the Caturra and Catuai varieties of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method (fermented in an oxygen-free environment, then dried in the whole fruit). Blind Assessment: Bright, sweetly tart. Cocoa nib, pie cherry, bay leaf, tangerine, pink peppercorn in aroma and cup. Juicy, sweet-tart acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Resonant finish centered around cocoa nib and pink peppercorn notes.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of the Kibugu Farmer's Cooperative Society, from trees of the SL28, Batian and Ruiru 11 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Blind Assessment: Gently tart, chocolaty. Lemon balm, cocoa powder, date, cedar sassafras in aroma and cup. Bright, winy acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Gently drying finish consolidates to notes of lemon balm, cedar and cocoa powder.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Costa Rica and Colombia, including Geisha, Bourbon and  Typica varieties of Arabica, al natural-processed. CoffeeBox Coffee founders Godfrey and Coco focus on small-batch coffee roasting with the goal of making the joy of premium coffee accessible to everyone. Visit

Coffee Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia

Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Notes: A blend of coffees from Guatemala (washed) and Ethiopia (both washed and natural). Certified USDA Organic and Kosher. Counter Culture was founded as a roastery in North Carolina in 1995 and has since expanded to 12 training centers across the U.S. Visit

Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers of the Asociación San Roque, entirely of the Caturra variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Founded in Philadelphia in 1994 by Todd Carmichael and JP Iberti, La Colombe is now owned by Chobani. Visit

Blind Assessment: Rich-toned, earthy-sweet. Fresh humus, cocoa powder, gently scorched sandalwood, gardenia, graphite in aroma and cup. Gentle, almost imperceptible acidity; dry vermouth-like mouthfeel. Earthy sweet finish with hints of cocoa powder underneath.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers and processed by the traditional Indonesian wet-hulled method. Peet’s Coffee, founded by Alfred Peet in 1966, is now owned by JAB Holding Company. Visit

Blind Assessment: Sweetly smoky, citrusy. Gently scorched Meyer lemon zest, mesquite, dark chocolate, lily, hazelnut in aroma and cup. Low-toned, jagged acidity; tannic, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Smoky-citrusy wood-framed finish.
Notes: An Ethiopia from undisclosed regions of Ethiopia, processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Peet’s Coffee, founded by Alfred Peet in 1966, is now owned by JAB Holding Company. Visit

Blind Assessment: Roast-muted, wood-framed. Earthy, sweetly savory. Treacle, fresh-turned soil, scorched fir, lily, date in aroma and cup. Sharp, astringent acidity; bitter but viscous mouthfeel. Smoky, woody finish with undertones of lily.
Notes: No origin information provided except “Sumatra.” Starbucks Corporation is an American multinational chain of coffeehouses and roastery reserves headquartered in Seattle, Washington. Visit

Blind Assessment: Harsh, bitter. Charcoal, snap pea, soapy florals, carob, stale raising in aroma and cup. Harsh, bitter acidity; droopy mouthfeel. Woody, burnt finish.

Notes: Produced at Finca San Martin, entirely of the Bourbon Aji variety of Arabica, and processed by the co-fermented honey method, in which the whole fruit is fermented with starfruit and peaches, and then some of the fruit flesh is left on the beans during the drying process. Blind Assessment: Elegant, floral-toned, sweetly herbaceous. Narcissus, agave syrup, dried apricot, marjoram, salted almond in aroma and cup. Delicately bright, gently tart acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Very long, flavor-saturated, harmonious finish.
Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It is processed by the anaerobic natural method, fermented with mosto, fresh-pressed juice from the coffee fruit. Founded in 2013, modcup coffee focuses on fresh roasting and distinctive natural-processed coffees. This special release is available to members of modcup’s Deepcuts list. Visit

Notes: Produced by the Lamustus Family of Elida Estate, entirely of the Green-Tip Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method, specifically DRD (dark-room-dried). Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It is processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Heat Coffee is a nano-roaster in Taipei, Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest-quality coffee. Visit the

Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-tart, high-toned. Jasmine, hazelnut, cocoa nib, tangerine, lychee in aroma and cup. Bright, citric acidity; smooth, silky mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned finish supported by notes of jasmine and tangerine.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before the drying process). Heat Coffee is a nano-roaster in Taipei, Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest-quality coffee. Visit the

Blind Assessment: Earthy-sweet, richly nutty. Cashew butter, fresh humus, dark chocolate, golden raisin, fir in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet-savory acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Nutty finish supported by dark chocolate tones.
Notes: A blend comprised of two coffees, a wet-hulled Suatra and a semi-washed Brazil. Ba Yang is a specialty coffee roaster based in New Taipei City, Taiwan.  Visit

Blind Assessment: Deeply sweet-savory, rich-toned. Dark chocolate, date, fresh-cut fir, cashew butter, gardenia in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; very full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Gently drying finish centered around dark chocolate and fresh-cut fir.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Ethiopia and Brazil.  Heat Coffee is a nano-roaster in Taipei, Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest-quality coffee. Visit the

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Gesha Village Surma 1931 Mossto Anaerobic Honey
Blind Assessment: Fruit-forward, gently spice-toned, floral. Cantaloupe, narcissus, nutmeg, cocoa nib, amber in aroma and cup. Juicy, balanced acidity; vibrantly silky, very smooth mouthfeel. Long, lingering, fruity and floral finish.
Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It is processed by the honey method (some fruit flesh is left on the beans during the drying process). Bear Lake Coffee Co., a B Corp-certified coffeehouse and roastery located in Barronett, Wisconsin, is committed to sustainability through its Coffee with a Purpose™ initiative, which ensures that farmers receive compensation well above the Fairtrade Premium for their exceptional small-batch coffee. Visit

Coffee Name: Some Serious Gourmet Sh*t Sumatra Mandheling Natural
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra, Indonesia
Blind Assessment: Bright, balanced, juicy. Sweet-tarts candy, cocoa powder, freesia, sugarcane, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart, malic (apple-like) acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Delicately sweet, gently tart finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Mortem Labs is a Norfolk, Virginia roastery that offers small-batch blends and select single-origin coffees. Visit

Coffee Origin: Volcan Baru, Boquete growing region, Panama
Blind Assessment: High-toned, delicately aromatic. Bergamot, star jasmine, Meyer lemon zest, cocoa nib, myrrh in aroma and cup. Bright, sparkling acidity; very smooth, live, silky mouthfeel. Very long, flavor-saturated finish that honors the promise of the cup.
Notes: Produced by Priscilla Sitton of Bambito Estate, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method, in which the fruit skin and pulp are removed from the beans before drying. Mostra Coffee is a women-, minority-, veteran-, and immigrant-owned micro-roaster based in north county San Diego. For more information, visit

Blind Assessment: Complex, fruit-driven, vibrant. Passionfruit, cocoa butter, rose hips, lavender, blood orange in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy, phosphoric acidity; very syrupy mouthfeel. Richly aromatic, nuanced finish consolidates to notes of cocoa butter and lavender.
Notes: Produced by Efren Echeverry of Las Palmas Coffee, entirely of the Pink Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by a variation on the honey method that includes 48 hours of oxidation, followed by a fruit-must inoculation and a 170-hour fermentation. Utopian Coffee is a specialty roaster based in Fort Wayne, Indiana. Visit

Coffee Origin: San Antonio La Paz, El Progreso Department, Guatemala
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-savory, rich-toned. Baking chocolate, red plum, almond, apple blossom, salted caramel in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; very full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Chocolaty finish with undertones of almond and salted caramel.
Notes: Produced by Higinio Gómez of Beneficio La Esperanza, from trees of the Yellow Pacamara varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried).

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Sidama Bensa Hamasho Washed G1 74158
Blind Assessment: High-toned, crisply sweet. Apricot, almond, tangerine, cocoa nib, lemon verbena in aroma and cup. Gently bright, citrusy acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned finish supported by tangerine and lemon verbena.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the 74158 variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed from the beans before drying). Libero Coffee is a specialty coffee shop and roaster in Taipei. Visit

Blind Assessment: Delicately fruity, crisply chocolaty. Goji berry, baking chocolate, hazelnut, lime zest, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Sweetly brisk acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Nutty, chocolaty finish.
Notes: Produced by Diego Robelo of Finca Aquiares, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which whole fruit is fermented with limited oxygen before drying. The Westside Coffee Company is a Utah-based specialty coffee roaster and cafe. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Richly nut-toned, crisply chocolaty. Hazelnut butter, dark chocolate, vanilla bean, date, cedar in aroma and small cup. Crisp, satiny mouthfeel; cedary, vanilla-toned finish. In cappuccino format, deeply sweet, richly nutty, balanced.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Brazil, Colombia and Indonesia, roasted for espresso applications. Coffee By The Grand is a culinary center in Hong Kong with shops, restaurants and a bakery. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Richly sweet-tart, crisply chocolaty. Raspberry, baking chocolate, brown sugar, orange zest, fresh-cut oak in aroma and small cup. Velvety-smooth mouthfeel; quiet, chocolaty finish with undertones of orange zest. In cappuccino format, raspberry and baking chocolate notes are pleasingly amplified.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Colombia, Ethiopia and Guatemala, roasted for espresso applications. Coffee By The Grand is a culinary center in Hong Kong with shops, restaurants and a bakery. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Deep-toned, crisply chocolaty. Cocoa powder, nutmeg, golden raisin, fresh-cut fir, orange zest in aroma and small cup. Crisp, velvety mouthfeel; chocolaty, spice-toned finish. In cappuccino format, richly chocolaty with undertones of nutmeg, fir and orange zest.
Notes: A blend designed for both drip and espresso applications. Mercurys Coffee Co. is a Bellevue, Washington-based roastery that has 12 cafes throughout the region. Visit

Blind Assessment: Deeply savory, sweetly tart. Jolly Rancher, hop flowers, halvah, pineapple kefir, hint of sweet soy in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet-savory acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Savory-leaning finish redolent of halvah and sweet soy.
Notes: Produced by five smallholding family farmers, entirely of the Coffea Liberica species, a coffee native to central Africa and long cultivated in parts of Southeast Asia. Processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which whole cherries are fermented in an oxygen-free environment before being dried in the whole fruit. City Boy Coffee is a specialty roaster based in Long Island City, New York. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Richly chocolaty, sweetly nut-toned. Pomegranate, chocolate fudge, butterscotch, almond, marjoram in aroma and small cup. Creamy, viscous mouthfeel; chocolaty, richly nutty finish. As a cappuccino, exceptionally chocolaty and very rich.
Notes: A blend of 70% washed Guatemala coffee blended with other undisclosed origins and named after a Hawaiian bird of cultural significance. Big Island Coffee Roasters is an award-winning coffee roaster operated with hands-on passion by Kelleigh Stewart and Brandon von Damitz. Visit

Coffee Origin: Kona and Ka’u, Hawai’i; other undisclosed origins
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Delicately aromatic, floral-toned. Freesia, dark chocolate, hazelnut butter, lychee, cedar in aroma and small cup. Syrupy-smooth mouthfeel; crisp, chocolaty finish. In cappuccino format, richly floral, crisply chocolaty and sweetly nutty.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Ka’u and Kona, Hawai’i and other undisclosed origins. Big Island Coffee Roasters is an award-winning coffee roaster operated with hands-on passion by Kelleigh Stewart and Brandon von Damitz. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Richly sweet, gently roast-rounded. Baking chocolate, Fig Newton, gently scorched cedar, gardenia, orange zest in aroma and small cup. Crisp, velvety mouthfeel; chocolaty finish with undertones of gently scorched cedar. In milk, complex and invitingly nuanced with notes of aking chocolate, orange zest, and gardenia.
Notes: A blend of 70% washed Guatemala coffee blended with other undisclosed origins and named after a Hawaiian bird of cultural significance. Big Island Coffee Roasters is an award-winning coffee roaster operated with hands-on passion by Kelleigh Stewart and Brandon von Damitz. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Gently bright, balanced. Hazelnut, cocoa nib, goji berry, candied violet, oak in aroma and cup. Plush, satiny mouthfeel; quiet, nutty and cocoa-toned finish. As cappuccino, richly nut-toned with sweet floral impulses.
Notes: A blend of 70% washed Guatemala coffee blended with other undisclosed origins and named after a Hawaiian bird of cultural significance. Big Island Coffee Roasters is an award-winning coffee roaster operated with hands-on passion by Kelleigh Stewart and Brandon von Damitz. Visit

Blind Assessment: Rich-toned, balanced and deep. Dark chocolate, nutmeg, almond butter, tangerine, fresh-cut cedar in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Chocolaty, spice-toned finish, resonant and long.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Kenya (Iria-Ini Farmer's Cooperative Society) and Sumatra (Koerintji Barokah Bersama Cooperative) in a special collaboration with artist David Persue.​​ Jaunt Coffee Roasters is a San Diego-based roaster and café with an extensive coffee and food menu. Visit

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, candylike. Candied violet, dried red plum, cocoa nib, marjoram, pink peppercorn in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; very full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned finish supported by notes of candied violet and marjoram.
Notes: Produced by Jose Gomez and his son, Jose Gomez, Jr., entirely of the Catimor variety of Arabica, and processed by the honey method, in which some of the fruit flesh is left on the beans during the drying process. True Coffee is a specialty roaster and cafe in Wisconsin whose motto is, “On a never-ending quest to bring you a great cup of coffee, by staying true to the bean.” Visit

Blind Assessment: Gently fruit-toned, richly floral. Yellow plum, agave syrup, plumeria, nutmeg, cocoa nib in aroma and cup. Crisp citrusy acidity; A clean,plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Resonant finish consolidates to cocoa nib and nutmeg, with undercurrents of plumeria.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers in the Bensa District of the Sidamo Zone, from selections of landrace varieties of Arabica native to Ethiopia, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit) at the Ayla Testi Washing Station.JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Blind Assessment: Floral-toned, deeply fruity. Narcissus, mangosteen, lychee, bergamot, almond butter in aroma and cup. High-toned, malic (apple-like) acidity; crisp, stainy mouthfeel. Exceptionally long, harmonious, resonant finish.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez of Granja Paraiso 92, entirely of the Striped Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with a strain of Lactobacillus for 24 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Afterward, the washed parchment coffee is rapidly dried with an in-house designed Eco-Enigma dehumidifying dryer to avoid over-oxidation or continued fermentation. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Blind Assessment: Delicately pungent, sweetly tart. Rose hips, dried raspberry, cocoa nib, finger lime, marjoram in aroma and cup. Gently bright, balanced acidity; vibrant, sparkling acidity. Crisply tart, berry-toned finish supported by notes of cocoa nib and marjoram.
Notes: Produced by Jamir Munoz of Finca Buena Vista, entirely of the Pink Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia region, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Balanced, quietly confident. Pink grapefruit, amber, apricot, green peppercorn, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Gently bright, juicy acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Sweetly citrusy finish with a green peppercorn-like spice note.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from selections of landrace varieties of Arabica native to Ethiopia, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Blind Assessment: Complex, elegant, lush. Oolong tea, pistachio, jujube, freesia, allspice in aroma and cup. Juicy-tart-savory structure with sparkling acidity; very full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. A wild honey note surfaces in the finish, supporting freesia, jujube and allspice.
Notes: Produced by members of the GuKeng Farmers Association, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying).

Coffee Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Elegant, high-toned, sweetly tart. Apricot nectar, almond butter, cocoa nib, bergamot, amber, lemon verbena in aroma and cup. Juicy, citrusy acidity; vibrant, silky-smooth mouthfeel. Long, resonantly sweet, invigoratingly tart finish that fulfills the promise of the cup.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of landrace selections of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious, high-quality coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Exceptionally aromatic, complex, deeply floral. White rose, mango lassi, almond butter, pink grapefruit, amber in aroma and cup. Intensely sweet structure with
Notes: Produced by Luis Anibal Calderon of Finca Betulia, entirely of the Sidra variety of Arabica, and processed by the carbonic maceration method, which involves fermenting the whole fruit in a sealed container that has been flushed with CO2, then drying in the whole fruit. Corvus particularly focuses on processing methods and selective harvesting, which results in small, seasonal micro-lots of uniquely sweet, vibrant and clean flavor profiles. Coffee Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Fruit-centered, richly chocolaty. Berry melange, chocolate fudge, pink peppercorn, lemon balm, candied violet in aroma and cup. in aroma and cup. Tart, winey acidity; very full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Resonant, long, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Produced by Ato and Daniel Mijane, from trees of local heirloom varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural anaerobic method, in which whole fruit is fermented with limited oxygen before drying. Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious, high-quality coffee. Visit

Coffee Name: Costa Rica Hacienda Sonora Natural Milenio
Blind Assessment: Fruit-forward, chocolaty, sweetly herbaceous. Cheerwine cola, pomegranate, bay leaf, almond, dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Bight, juicy-sweet acidity; very full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Resonant finish consolidates to notes of Cheerwine cola and bay leaf with dark chocolate undertones.
Notes: Produced by Diego Guardia and his family of Hacienda Sonora, entirely of the Milenia variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Corvus particularly focuses on processing methods and selective harvesting, which results in small, seasonal micro-lots of uniquely sweet, vibrant and clean flavor profiles. Blind Assessment: Intensely sweet, gently tart. Dark caramel, dried plum, lavender, cantaloupe, cocoa nib in aroma and cup. Sparkling acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Finish centers around notes of dark caramel and lavender.
Notes: Produced by Doña Francisca and Oscar Chacon of Finca Las Lajas, from trees of the Caturra, Catuai and Villa Sarchi varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious, high-quality coffee. Visit

Coffee Name: El Salvador Finca Santa Sofia Natural Kenya
Blind Assessment: Complex, crisply sweet-savory. Sesame seed, dried mulberry, amber, cocoa nib, cedar in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet, gently tart acidity; crisp, silky mouthfeel. Very long, flavor-saturated, deep-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by the Pacas Family, entirely of the heirloom Kenya variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Corvus particularly focuses on processing methods and selective harvesting, which results in small, seasonal micro-lots of uniquely sweet, vibrant and clean flavor profiles. Blind Assessment: Gently fruit-forward, cocoa-toned. Cocoa nib, watermelon, lychee, macadamia nut, wild honey in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy, balanced acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Very long, sweet and deep-toned finish, harmoniously integrating all the aromas and flavors of the cup.
Notes: Produced by indigenous Inga farmers in the native reservation of Aponte in Nariño, Colombia, from trees of the Caturra and Colombia varieties of Arabica, and processed by the honey method, in which some of the fruit flesh is left on the beans during the drying process. Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious, high-quality coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Sweet-toned, crisply chocolaty. Bing cherry, hazelnut, baking chocolate, toffee, pink grapefruit zest in aroma and cup. Balanced, vibrant acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Chocolaty, sweetly nutty finish with undertones of pink grapefruit zest.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Colombia and Ethiopia (natural, washed and honey-processed). Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious, high-quality coffee. Visit

Coffee Name: Guatemala Maravilla La Cumbre Washed Pache
Blind Assessment: Deeply, chocolaty, sweet and rich. Dark chocolate, hazelnut, brown sugar, tiger lily, lemon balm in aroma and cup. Gentle, sweet-toned acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Chocolaty, sweetly nutty finish.
Notes: Produced by Mauricio Rosales of Finca La Maravilla, entirely of the Pache variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Corvus particularly focuses on processing methods and selective harvesting, which results in small, seasonal micro-lots of uniquely sweet, vibrant and clean flavor profiles. For more information, visit

Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-savory. Hop flowers, date, marjoram, satsuma mandarin, salted caramel in aroma and cup. Gently brisk, bittersweet acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. Crisp, sweet-savory finish centered around notes of hop flowers and salted caramel.
Notes: Produced by Luis Andrade of Finca La Curva, from trees of the Yellow Catuai and Castilla varieties of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic washed method, in which in which, after skin and pulp removal, fermentation takes place in a hermetically sealed vessel before the beans are washed and dried. Exported by Caracas Coffee Trade. Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious, high-quality coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Sweetly tart, rich-toned. Tamarind, dark chocolate, wine barrel, magnolia, nutmeg in aroma and cup. Crisply sweet, winey acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Long, resonant, flavor-laden finish that fulfills the promise of the cup.
Notes: Produced by Jaime Guevara of his eponymous farm, entirely of the Pacamara variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Conscious Cup Coffee Roasters is an independent and family-owned and -operated cafe and coffee roaster specializing in socially and environmentally sustainable coffees. Visit

Blind Assessment: Bright, juicy, floral-toned. Lemon blossom, myrrh, sage honey, almond, white peppercorn in aroma and cup. Rich, high-toned acidity; silky, vibrant mouthfeel. Sage honey and myrrh carry the rich-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by Alejandro Solís of Finca Huixoc entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried).

Blind Assessment: High-toned, sweet-tart, cocoa-toned. Cocoa nib, pomegranate, magnolia, lemon verbena, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with brisk acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of cocoa nib with undertones of magnolia and lemon verbena.
Notes: Produced at Finca Santa Elisa, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried).

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, deeply nut-toned. Hazelnut, apricot, tangerine, cedar, jasmine in aroma and cup. Crisp, malic (apple-like) acidity; velvety-smooth mouthfeel. Floral-toned finish supported by rich hazelnut notes.
Notes: Produced by Josué Morales of Finca La Esperanza entirely of the Villa Sarchi variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). Certified USDA Organic. El Gran Cafe is a coffee shop located in the heart of Antigua, Guatemala whose mission is to roast and serve organic-certified coffees produced at its own Finca La Esperanza and Finca El Pintado just outside of town. Featured in El Gran Cafe’s lineup are also coffees from friends and neighbors in the region, along with award-winning and exceptional coffees from other regions of Guatemala. Visit

Coffee Name: El Salvador Finca Plan de Hoyo
Blind Assessment: Elegant, cocoa-toned, gently citrusy. Cocoa nib, tangerine, pink peppercorn, agave syrup, bay leaf in aroma and cup. Malic (apple-like acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned, citrusy finish.
Notes: Produced by Francisco De Sola of Finca Plan de Hoyo, entirely of the Anacafe 14 variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Conscious Cup Coffee Roasters is an independent and family-owned and -operated cafe and coffee roaster specializing in socially and environmentally sustainable coffees. Visit

Coffee Name: Espresso Np. 7 Fincas Las Moritas Pacamaras
Coffee Origin: San Antonio La Paz, El Progreso Department, Guatemala
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Chocolaty-sweet, deep-toned. Chocolate fudge, salted caramel, hop flowers, dried plum, tangerine in aroma and cup. Crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Richly chocolaty finish supported by hop flowers. In cappuccino format, chocolate notes predominate, with undertones of savory caramel and bitter sweet florals.
Notes: Produced by Higinio Gómez of Beneficio La Esperanza, from trees of the Yellow and Red Pacamara varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried).

Blind Assessment: Richly nut-toned floral. Pistachio, honeysuckle, red apple, cedar, pink grapefruit zest in aroma and cup. Bright, sparkling acidity; satiny mouthfeel. Pistachio and honeysuckle carry the resonant finish, with hints of pink grapefruit zest underneath.
Notes: Produced by Andres Fahsen of Finca Retana entirely of the Maracaturra variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried).

Coffee Origin: San Juan Sacatepequez, Sacatepequez Department, Guatemala
Blind Assessment: High-toned, crisply sweet-tart. Tamarind, cashew butter, Meyer lemon zest, cedar in aroma and cup. Bright, vibrant acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. Finish leads with notes of tamarind and cashew butter.
Notes: Produced by the same family for the past three generations in the high mountains of San Juan Sacatepéquez, from trees of the rare, ancient Geisha Malawi variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried).

Coffee Origin: Todos Santos Cuchumatán, Huehuetenango Department, Guatemala
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet, nut-toned. Cashew brittle, pie cherry, carnation, baking chocolate, mesquite in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned with brisk acidity; very syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Finish is characterized by notes of baking chocolate, carnation and mesquite.
Notes: Produced by Macario in the high mountains of Todos Santos from trees of the Pacamara variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried).

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-savory. Baking chocolate, yellow golden raisin, nougat, cedar, freesia in aroma and cup. Brisk acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. The wood-framed finish has a hint of a crisp chocolate undertones.
Notes: Produced by Alejandro Solís of Finca Huixoc entirely of the Pacamara variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). Coffee Origin: Chirripo, Brunca growing region, Costa Rica
Blind Assessment: Berry-toned, elegantly sweet-tart. Berry melange, fresh cream, lemon verbena, Nutella, cedar in aroma and cup. Juicy-bright, balanced acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Crisply chocolaty, sweetly herbaceous finish.
Notes: Produced at Rivense’s Finca El Mango, from trees of the Caturra and Catuai varieties of Arabica, and processed by the honey method, in which some of the fruit flesh is left on the beans during the drying process. Blind Assessment: Multi-layered, richly sweet-tart. Pomegranate, hibiscus tea, lemon balm, cocoa nib, fresh-cut cedar in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet-tart acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. Very sweet, candy-like finish with undertones of rich cedar.

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Deeply chocolaty, sweetly nut-toned. Dark chocolate, roasted hazelnut, lemon curd, balsa wood, molasses in aroma and small cup. Creamy-smooth mouthfeel; crisp, chocolaty, nutty finish. In cappuccino format, balanced, deep-toned, richly sweet.

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-savory. Black currant, narcissus, tamarind, cedar, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Complex, bittersweet structure with high-toned acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. Sweetly tart finish leads with tamarind notes, supported by narcissus and cedar.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Sidama Bensa Hamasho Washed TOH#2
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, deeply aromatic. Magnolia, dried pear, cocoa nib, lemon balm, ginger candy. Juicy-bright acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned finish with notes of ginger candy and magnolia.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the 74158 variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Sweetly tart, fruity and chocolaty. Pomegranate, dark chocolate, tangerine, pink peppercorn, amber in aroma and cup. Bright, balanced acidity; gentle, silky mouthfeel. Chocolaty, fruit-toned finish.
Notes: A blend of three coffees, two from Ethiopia (one washed, one natural-processed) and a washed El Salvador. Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Multi-layered, deeply sweet-tart. Dried cranberry, hibiscus tea, lemon verbena, cocoa nib, fresh-cut cedar in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Very sweet, fruit-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the 74158 variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Complex, multi-layered. Candied violet, satsuma mandarin, almond, dark chocolate, oak in aroma and cup. Malic (apple-like) acidity; very full, satiny mouthfeel. Sweetly tart finish centered around notes of citrus and candied violet.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed at the Dembi Station by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Rusty Dog Coffee is a Madison, Wisconsin-based specialty coffee roaster. Visit

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, nut toned. Macadamia butter, baking chocolate, pineapple, agave syrup, cedar in aroma and cup. Gently brisk acidity; very full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Crisp, long, resonant finish centered around notes of baking chocolate and macadamia nut.
Notes: Produced by Concepcion Villatoro of Finca Los Dos Socios, entirely of the Caturra variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Utopian Coffee is a specialty roaster based in Fort Wayne, Indiana. Visit

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-tart, citrusy and bright. Blood orange, baking chocolate, agave syrup, freesia, cedar in aroma and cup. Brisk, tart-leaning acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The long finish leads with notes of baking chocolate and blood orange.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Rusty Dog Coffee is a Madison, Wisconsin-based specialty coffee roaster. Visit

Coffee Origin: La Paz, Marcala growing region, Honduras
Blind Assessment: Chocolaty-sweet, gently fruit-forward. Dark chocolate, watermelon candy, cashew, pink grapefruit zest, fresh-cut oak in aroma and cup. Bright, balanced acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of dark chocolate and pink grapefruit zest.
Notes: Produced by Edgar and Karen Carillo of Pacayal Coffee, entirely of the Typica variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Regenerative Organic Certified® (ROC™). Utopian Coffee is a specialty roaster based in Fort Wayne, Indiana. Visit

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, crisply chocolaty. Cocoa powder, Brazil nut, date, molasses, hint of gardenia in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned finish supported by molasses and Brazil nut.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the Typica, Bourbon and Marsellesa varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit) and decaffeinated using ethyl acetate, a solvent derived from sugar cane. Blind Assessment: Sweet-toned, crisp and gently bright. Pomelo, apple blossom, cocoa nib, fir, sassafras in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of sassafras and fir.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the Catimor variety of Arabica, and processed by the black honey method, in which some of the fruit flesh is left on the beans during the drying process. Rusty Dog Coffee is a Madison, Wisconsin-based specialty coffee roaster. Visit

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-savory, deep-toned. Red currant, ripe tomato, dark chocolate, cedar, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Lively, balanced acidity; plush, crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Long, resonant, flavor-saturated, harmonious finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of the Murue Farmer's Cooperative, from trees of the SL-28, SL-34, Ruiru 11, Batian and K7 varieties of Arabica, and processed at the Ngrueri Coffee Factory by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Notes: Produced by Maria Alexandra Rivera and Galo Morales and their extended family at Finca Cruz Loma, entirely of the Sidra variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet, quietly tart. Pear, plumeria, cocoa nib, cedar, hint of amber in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; very smooth, satiny mouthfeel. Quite sweet finish with notes of pear and plumeria.
Notes: Produced by Arnulfo Leguizamo and his son Diego of Finca El Faldon, entirely of the Caturra variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Coffee Name: Colombia Monteblanco Nectar Citrullus Secret Stash
Blind Assessment: Exceptionally sweet, gently tart. Passionfruit, honeydew melon, baking chocolate, bergamot, myrrh in aroma and cup. Crisp, mild acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Long, resonant, lingering, complex finish.
Notes: Produced by Rodrigo Sanchez and Claudia Samboni of Finca Monteblanco, from trees of the Caturra and Bourbon varieties of Arabica, and processed by the washed method with the addition of Citrullus fruit (melon of various types) to the fermentation. Old Soul is a roastery, bakery, and crafter of artisanal goods dedicated to quality in every form. Visit

Coffee Name: Costa Rica La Laguna Lot Secret Stash
Blind Assessment: Chocolaty-rich, deeply fruit-forward. Wild raspberry, milk chocolate, freesia, pink peppercorn, oak in aroma and cup. Vibrant, sparkling acidity; very full, satiny mouthfeel. Milk chocolate and raspberry commingle in the finish.
Notes: Produced by the Mora Family, entirely of the Caturra variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Old Soul is a roastery, bakery, and crafter of artisanal goods dedicated to quality in every form. Visit

Coffee Name: Costa Rica La Casilla Secret Stash
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, deep-toned. Agave syrup, guava, cocoa nib, lemon verbena, cedar in aroma and cup. Gently citrusy acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The cocoa-driven finish has undertones of lemon verbena and agave.
Notes: Produced by Pito and Jose Solis, entirely of the Typica variety of Arabica, and processed by the honey method, in which some of the fruit flesh is left on the beans during the drying process. Old Soul is a roastery, bakery, and crafter of artisanal goods dedicated to quality in every form. Visit

Coffee Name: Costa Rica La Pastora Secret Stash
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-tart, fruity. Watermelon taffy, dark chocolate, salted caramel, cedar, tangerine in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet, tart-leaning acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Crisp, bold finish centers around notes of watermelon taffy and tangerine.
Notes: Produced by Carlos and Jacob Montero, from trees of the Red Catuai and Caturra varieties of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which the coffee is fermented in the whole fruit with limited access to oxygen before drying. Old Soul is a roastery, bakery, and crafter of artisanal goods dedicated to quality in every form. Visit

Coffee Name: Colombia El Mirador Natural Secret Stash
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, deeply chocolaty, fruit-forward. Chocolate fudge, strawberry, marjoram, Meyer lemon zest, cashew butter in aroma and cup. Bright, balanced acidity; rich, velvety mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of chocolate fudge and marjoram.
Notes: Produced by Elkin Guzman of Finca El Mirador, entirely of the Tabi variety of Arabica, and processed by the thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented, then given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Afterward, the washed parchment is rapidly dried quickly to avoid over-oxidation or continued fermentation. Old Soul is a roastery, bakery, and crafter of artisanal goods dedicated to quality in every form. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Deep-toned, richly fruity and chocolaty. Dark chocolate, goji berry, purple plum, pink grapefruit, cedar in aroma and small cup. Plush, creamy mouthfeel; chocolaty, citrusy finish. Everything is amplified in cappuccino format,  especially the dark chocolate and purple plum notes.
Notes: A blend of two coffees, a natural Ethiopia and a pulped natural Brazil. Roasted for espresso applications. Barrington Coffee is an artisan roaster dedicated to elite coffees, fresh delivery, and roasting that foregrounds the coffee and not the roast. Visit

Sweetly tart structure with high-toned, balanced acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of cocoa-toned strawberry with sweet herb undertones.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Blind Assessment: Richly aromatic, sweetly tart. Tamarind, gardenia, fir, pistachio, pink grapefruit zest in aroma and cup. Sweetly tarty structure with gently brisk acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Gently drying finish centered around notes of tamarind and fir with pistachio undertones.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which, after skin and pulp removal, fermentation takes place in a hermetically sealed vessel before the beans are de-pulped and dried. Blind Assessment: Cocoa-toned, crisply sweet. Cocoa nib, yellow plum, orange zest, cedar, magnolia in aroma and cup. Sweet in structure with crisp, balanced acidity; smooth, silky mouthfeel. Cocoa nib notes carry the finish, with hints of plum and orange zest in the long.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). David's Nose is a specialty coffee roaster based in Taipei, Taiwan whose founder studied agronomy and has a deep interest in crop quality. For more information, visit

Coffee Name: Panama Lamastus Family Elida Estate Loma Geisha Washed
Blind Assessment: Elegant, delicate, quietly complex. Bergamot, cocoa nib, apricot, almond, star jasmine in aroma and cup. Malic (apple-like) acidity; vibrant, very silky mouthfeel. Harmonious, integrated, nuanced, finish.
Notes: Produced by the Lamastus Family of Elida Estate, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying. Taster’s Coffee is a nano-roaster based in New Taipei City, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Name: Colombia Santa Monica Pink Bourbon Honey Co-Ferment Strawberry
Blind Assessment: Distinctly berry-toned, crisply sweet-tart. Wild strawberry, cocoa nib, lemon verbena, honey, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Gently bright, juicy acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. Strawberry and cocoa nib lead in the resonant finish.
Notes: Produced by Jairo Arcila, entirely of the Pink Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, with the addition of wine yeast and strawberries to the fermentation. Established in 2009 by Amy and Scott Angelo, Oceana brews specialty coffees that have been roasted in small batches at its roasting house and café in Tequesta, Florida. Visit

Blind Assessment: Delicately floral, sweetly tropical. Lilac, lychee, tangerine, cocoa nib, lemon thyme in aroma and cup. Gently bright, floral acidity; crisp, silky-smooth mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned finish with lychee and tangerine undertones.
Notes: Produced by the Rodriguez family of Finca Alasitas, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the cocoa natural method, meaning the beans are partially dried in the whole fruit on raised beds, then transferred to a cocoa box to dry slowly at a low temperature over time. Coffee Cycle Roasting is a San Diego-based specialty roaster founded by cycling enthusiasts. Visit

Coffee Name: Colombia Finca Juan Martin Sidra Natural
Blind Assessment: Richly fruit-centric, flavor-saturated. Lavender, cherry candy, Orange Crush, baking chocolate, oak in aroma and cup. Brisk, citrusy acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Lavender and cherry candy carry the focused finish.
Notes: Produced at Finca Juan Martin, owned and operated by Banexport, entirely of the Sidra variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Established in 2009 by Amy and Scott Angelo, Oceana brews specialty coffees that have been roasted in small batches at its roasting house and café in Tequesta, Florida. Visit

Blind Assessment: Rich-toned, earthy-sweet. Pipe tobacco, date, cedar, rhododendron, sage in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; plush, creamy-smooth mouthfeel. Resonant, aromatic finish centered around notes of pipe tobacco and date.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the Ateng, Jember and Garundang varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional Sumatra washed and wet-hulled method. Coffee Cycle Roasting is a San Diego-based specialty roaster founded by cycling enthusiasts. Visit

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-tart, fruit-centered. Bing cherry, hazelnut, candied violet, ginger, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Bright, tartly juicy acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Complex, multi-layered, very long finish.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez of Granja Paraiso 92, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with a strain of Lactobacillus for 24 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Afterward, the washed parchment coffee is rapidly dried with an in-house designed Eco-Enigma dehumidifying dryer to avoid over-oxidation or continued fermentation. SÖT Coffee Roaster, based in Osaka, Japan, is a self-described Swedish-style roaster with an “aggressively light” roasting style. For more information, visit

Blind Assessment: Citrusy-sweet, high-toned. Dried nectarine, almond, candied violet, Meyer lemon, cedar in aroma and cup. Briskly tart, citric acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Very long, flavor-saturated finish that honors the promise of the cup.
Notes: Produced by Tamiru Tedesse and the smallholding farmers of Chilaka Village, entirely of the 74158 of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Wonderstate Coffee, formerly Kickapoo Coffee, is an award-winning roaster based in rural Wisconsin known for its commitment to guaranteeing higher pay for farmers and operating the country’s first 100% solar-powered roastery. Visit

Blind Assessment: Candy-like, citrusy. Bergamot, Jolly Rancher, cocoa nib, lemon balm, fresh-cut oak in aroma and cup. Vibrant, citrusy acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Crisp, bittersweet, cocoa-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by Priscilla Gonzalez, entirely of the Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before dying). Founded by the co-owner of Olympia Coffee, Oliver Stormshak, who has worked in the coffee industry for more than three decades, Oliver’s Custom Coffee features rare varietals, experimental lots, and custom fermentations. Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, Hawai’i Island

Notes: Produced by Abby and Sal Muñoz of Monarch Farm, entirely of the Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic washed method with the addition of Champagne yeasts to the fermentation. Blind Assessment: Sweetly citrusy, spice-toned. Pomelo, vanilla orchid, red plum, pink peppercorn, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Balanced, citrusy acidity; very silky, viscous mouthfeel. Vanilla-like florals and pink peppercorn are supported by pomelo and red plum in the resonant finish.

Blind Assessment: Bright, balanced, tropical-leaning. Passionfruit, ginger blossom, cocoa nib, Meyer lemon zest, amber in aroma and cup. Delicate, high-toned acidity; satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawai’i

Notes: Produced by Karen and Lee Paterson, entirely of the SL34 variety of Arabica, and processed by whole-cherry co-fermentation with Kona oranges also grown on the Hula Daddy farm (originally brought to the island in 1792). Hula Daddy is a boutique coffee producer with farms at the 1,400 and 2,500-foot levels of the Mount Hualalai volcano near the northern end of the Kona growing district, five minutes above the town of Kailua-Kona. Blind Assessment: Jammy, chocolaty. Milk chocolate, blackberry jam, violet, thyme, oak in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolaty, fruity finish into the long.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez of Granja Paraiso 92, entirely of the Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed anaerobic method, in which in which, after skin and pulp removal, fermentation takes place in a hermetically sealed vessel before the beans are de-pulped and dried. Decaffeinated in Colombia using ethyl acetate, a solvent derived from sugar cane. Blind Assessment: Deeply sweet, fruit-driven, lively. Dried apricot, dark chocolate, marjoram, almond, pink grapefruit zest in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with bright, juicy acidity; full, creamy-smooth mouthfeel. The crisply fruit-toned finish is complicated by notes of almond and dark chocolate.
Notes: Produced by Tamiru Tadesse, from trees of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit

Coffee Name: Taiwan Natural Alishan Chi Tsai Liu Li Ecological Farm
Blind Assessment: Gently tart, richly high-toned. Meyer lemon zest, dark chocolate, narcissus, agave syrup, fresh-cut cedar in aroma and cup. Zesty, malic (apple-like) acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of sweet citrus and cocoa nib.
Notes: Produced by Chia-Jung Chuang, entirely of the Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Fruity, floral, flavor-saturated. Jolly Rancher, star jasmine, ginger root, wild raspberry, frankincense in aroma and cup. Phosphoric, winey acidity; lush, syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor-laden, very long, complex finish.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez of Finca La Macarena, entirely of the SL28 variety of Arabica, and processed by the thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented in an anaerobic bioreactor with Saccharomyces pastorianus yeast for 48-96 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Afterward, the washed parchment coffee is rapidly dried with an in-house designed Eco-Enigma dehumidifying dryer to avoid over-oxidation or continued fermentation. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Blind Assessment: Stone fruit-driven, cocoa- and floral-toned. Narcissus, cocoa nib, Bing cherry, lychee, bergamot in aroma and cup. High-toned, sparkling acidity; silky, delicate mouthfeel. Very long, focused finish that carries over all the aroma and flavor notes of the cup.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Notes: Produced by Camilo Merizalde of Finca Santuario, entirely of the Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Cozy House Coffee is a Taiwan-based specialty coffee roaster and an SCA Authorized Trainer (AST). For more information, visit the

Blind Assessment: Gently sweet-tart, deeply layered. Dried mulberry, honeysuckle, macadamia butter, cocoa nib, marjoram in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with winey acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of macadamia butter and cocoa nib with undertones of dried mulberry.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Cozy House Coffee is a Taiwan-based specialty coffee roaster and an SCA Authorized Trainer (AST). For more information, visit the

Blind Assessment: Berry-driven, cocoa-toned. Raspberry, cocoa nib, amber, lemon verbena, cedar in aroma and cup. Delicately bright acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of raspberry and cocoa nib with amber undertones.
Notes: A blend of two coffees, a washed Guatemala and an Ethiopia natural. Jaunt Coffee Roasters is a San Diego-based roaster and café with an extensive coffee and food menu. Visit

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Bench Maji Gori Gesha ORO Yeast Natural G1
Blind Assessment: Resonantly floral, gently fruity, cocoa-toned. Cocoa nib, narcissus, pomegranate, Meyer lemon zest, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Juicy, malic acidity; very full, quite satiny mouthfeel. Floral-toned, fruity finish supported by cocoa nib.
Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It is processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit) with the addition of ORO yeast. 1980 Cafe is a Tainan City, Taiwan-based specialty coffee roaster. Visit

Blind Assessment: Bright, juicy, fruit-centered. Apricot, blueberry, nutmeg, cocoa nib, lemon verbena in aroma and cup. Juicy-tart structure with citrusy acidity; quite full, syrupy mouthfeel. Long, resonant, flavor-laden finish.
Notes: A blend of coffees from undisclosed farms in Ethiopia. Coffeeland is a specialty coffee roastery with two locations, one in Chia-Yi, Taiwan, and one in Ontario, California. For more information, visit

Blind Assessment: Deeply savory, richly sweet, quite bright. Tamarind, dark chocolate, green tomato, marjoram, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweetly savory structure with juicy, high-toned acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. The very long, complex finish is savory-leaning and rich.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers and processed by the washed method (fruit skiing and pulp removed before drying). 1980 Cafe is a Tainan City, Taiwan-based specialty coffee roaster. Visit

Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). 1980 Cafe is a Tainan City, Taiwan-based specialty coffee roaster. Visit

Blind Assessment: Bright, juicy, nuanced. Delicately fruit-centered, richly sweet. Red plum, lemon verbena, myrrh, cocoa nib, watermelon candy in aroma and cup. Crisp, high-toned acidity; full, satiny mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of cocoa nib and lemon verbena.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez of Granja Paraiso 92, entirely of the Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with a strain of Lactobacillus for 24 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Afterward, the washed parchment coffee is rapidly dried with an in-house designed Eco-Enigma dehumidifying dryer to avoid over-oxidation or continued fermentation. Big Shoulders Coffee is a Chicago artisan roaster that emphasizes a fresh-roasted, no-nonsense approach to fine coffee. Visit

Coffee Name: Colombia Sebastian Ramirez Washed Pink Bourbon
Blind Assessment: Bright, juicy, harmonious. Peach, freesia, pink grapefruit zest, marjoram, cocoa nib in aroma and cup. Balanced, high-toned acidity; crisp, delicate mouthfeel. Finish centers around notes of peach and marjoram.
Notes: Produced by Sebastian Ramirez of Fincas El Placer, entirely of the Pink Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Shoulders Coffee is a Chicago artisan roaster that emphasizes a fresh-roasted, no-nonsense approach to fine coffee. Visit

Coffee Origin: Wensho Woreda, Sidamo growing region, Ethiopia

Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying) at the Dale Washing Station. Speedwell Coffee, based in Plymouth, Massachusetts, is a wholesale and retail specialty roaster particularly dedicated to offering attractive coffee subscription plans. For more information, visit

Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 9 coffee on

Blind Assessment: Complex, rich-toned. Watermelon candy, dried guava, pineapple taffy, cinnamon, toffee in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet, sparkling acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Harmonious, very long, deep-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by Martha Montenegro and her team of women pickers at El Vergel Estate, entirely of the Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method (fermented in an oxygen-free environment for 60 hours), then dried in the whole fruit. Torque Coffee has an unusual business model that promises 20 percent of the retail value of each coffee to its producer. Visit

Blind Assessment: Balanced, floral-toned. Cocoa nib, narcissus, apricot, almond, lemon balm in aroma and cup. Sparkling acidity; silky, viscous mouthfeel. Cohesive, satisfying finish that fulfills the promise of the cup.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Green Stone Coffee is a woman-owned artisan roastery in Taipei, Taiwan founded in 2016 and specializing in sourcing distinctive coffees that express their individual terroirs. Visit

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Washed Yirgacheffe Chelbesa SNNPR Gedeo G1
Blind Assessment: Elegantly sweet, spice-toned. Bergamot, plum, cashew, cocoa nib, lilac in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with vibrant acidity; very silky, viscous mouthfeel. The cocoa-toned finish has undertones of bergamot and plum.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of local landrace varieties, and proceeded by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Dou Zhai Coffee & Roastery is a Taiwan-based specialty coffee roaster and cafe. Visit

Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet, rich-toned. Cocoa nib, dried apricot, narcissus, hazelnut, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet structure with juicy acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. The finish centers around notes of cocoa-toned apricot.
Notes: A blend of coffees from three origins: a washed Colombia, a natural-processed Panama and a honey-processed Costa Rica. Dou Zhai Coffee & Roastery is a Taiwan-based specialty coffee roaster and cafe. Visit

Coffee Name: Colombia Lulo Wonka Wonka & Sebastian Gomez
Blind Assessment: Fruit-forward, deep-toned, enigmatic. Strawberry-guava, candied ginger, star jasmine, myrrh, lemongrass in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet-tart acidity; elegantly silky mouthfeel. Long, lingering, integrated finish.
Notes: This outstanding coffee was selected as the No. 23 coffee on

Blind Assessment: Intensely sweet, deeply aromatic. Magnolia, dried apricot, cocoa nib, lemon drop, pineapple taffy. Tart-savory acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned pineapple taffy and magnolia notes lead in the finish.
Notes: Produced by Juan Felipe of Finca La Reserva, entirely of the Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method (fermented in an oxygen-free environment for 96 hours), then dried in the whole fruit. Imported by Red Fox Coffee Merchants; certified USDA Organic. Blind Assessment: Gently fruity, richly chocolaty. Dark chocolate, mulberry, cashew butter, orange zest, oak in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; plush, creamy-smooth mouthfeel. Chocolaty finish with citrus and oak undertones.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of the Akisana Cooperative founded by Bodja Gelalecha and his family, from trees of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Founded in 2011 by Keith Hamrick and Jen Lovrak, Northbound Coffee Roasters is a family-owned and -operated roastery in Mount Shasta, California. Visit

Blind Assessment: Rich-toned, deeply sweet. Date, frangipane, freesia, baking chocolate, cedar in aroma and cup. Gently brisk, balanced acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Crisp, chocolaty finish with undertones of date and almond.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the Bourbon and Caturra varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Certified USDA Organic. Founded in 2011 by Keith Hamrick and Jen Lovrak, Northbound Coffee Roasters is a family-owned and -operated roastery in Mount Shasta, California. Visit

Blind Assessment: Delicately bright, balanced, multi-layered. Apricot, Meyer lemon, rhododendron, cocoa nib, marjoram in aroma and cup. Juicy-sweet, citrusy acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Long, resonant, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers in the Bensa District of the Sidamo Zone, from selections of landrace varieties of Arabica native to Ethiopia, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Blind Assessment: Crisply chocolaty, fruit-toned. Pie cherry, baking chocolate, almond, cedar, sassafras in aroma and cup. Bittersweet structure with gentle acidity; very full, satiny mouthfeel. Sweet-tart, nutty finish with a crisp chocolate throughline.
Notes: A blend of two coffees, an anaerobic washed Zambia and a washed Ethiopia. Caffè Luxxe is an Italian-inflected artisan roaster and retailer that emphasizes both its coffee knowledge and precision and its straightforward lack of pretension. Visit

Blind Assessment: Gently fruit- and spice-toned. Nutmeg, dried plum, hop flowers, cocoa powder, candied violet in aroma and cup. Gently brisk acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Nutmeg and hop flowers carry the quiet finish.
Notes: Produced at Hacienda La Minita, entirely of the Caturra variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which the whole fruit is fermented in tanks with limited oxygen before drying, also in the whole fruit. Blind Assessment: Fruit-forward, sweetly tart. Green apple, lemon kefir, amber, cocoa powder, fir in aroma and cup. Tart, gently drying acidity; full, creamy mouthfeel. Crisp, cocoa-driven finish supported by notes of green apple and amber.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which the whole fruit is fermented in tanks with limited oxygen before drying, also in the whole fruit. Based in Livingston, Montana, RamsHead Coffee Roasters is a family-owned company that specializes in direct trade microlot coffees. For more information, visit

Coffee Origin: Haro Wachu, Uraga, Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Ethiopia

Notes: Produced by Ocholo Bedecho and his family, from trees of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Blind Assessment: Crisply bittersweet, floral-toned. Osmanthus, hop flowers, fir, orange zest, thyme in aroma and cup. Briskly bittersweet acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. Gently drying finish with notes of osmanthus and fir.
Notes: A blend of two coffees: 75% Ethiopia Sidamo and 25% double-anaerobic Colombia co-fermented with osmanthus enzyme liquid and dried with ambient smoked osmanthus. Kafe Coffee Roastery is a specialty roaster based in Zhubei, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Name: Colombia Nestor Lasso El Diviso Chiroso
Blind Assessment: Delicately fruit-forward, resonantly tart. Pomegranate, lime zest, vanilla kefir, baking chocolate, cedar in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of pomegranate, kefir and cedar.

Coffee Name: Colombia Pink Champagne El Mirador Blend
Blind Assessment: Delicately fruit-forward, richly floral-toned. Wild raspberry, cocoa nib, narcissus, tangerine, amber in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. Exceptionally long, resonant, cohesive finish that maintains the harmony of the cup.
Notes: Produced at Finca El Mirador, from trees of the Caturra and Catiope varieties of Arabica, and processed by the carbonic maceration method, which involves fermenting the whole fruit in a sealed container that has been flushed with CO2, and drying in the whole fruit. Old World Coffee Roasters is a specialty coffee roaster with cafes in Reno and Carson City, Nevada. Visit

Coffee Origin: Valle de Cauca, Cauca Department, Colombia
Blind Assessment: Vibrant, high-toned, sweetly tart. Red plum, almond, lavender, pink grapefruit zest, olive leaf in aroma and cup. Sparkling acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Citrusy, spice-toned finish.

Coffee Name: Guatemala El Injerto Malawi Geisha Washed
Blind Assessment: Bright, sweet, lyric. An exhilarating range of flowers (rose, wisteria, plum blossom), bergamot, apple, pear, cocoa nib in aroma and cup. Sweetly high-toned and satiny in structure. Flavors layer and deepens in a long, resonant finish.
Notes: Produced at the admired El Injerto farm in the Huehuetenango growing region of Guatemala from trees of a rare strain of the celebrated Geisha variety long grown in the African nation of Malawi. Processed by the traditional washed method. GK Coffee is a nano-roastery in Yilan, Taiwan, that offers both retail and wholesale coffee. For more information, visit

Coffee Name: Guatemala El Injerto Legendary Geisha Natural Lot E1-06
Blind Assessment: Intense, richly bright and harmoniously complex. Aromatic orchid, passionfruit, cocoa nib, lemon verbena, honey in aroma and cup. Deeply sweet-tart in structure, full and syrupy in mouthfeel. Chocolate surfaces distinctly in the long, clean finish.
Notes: Produced at the admired El Injerto farm in the Huehuetenango growing region of Guatemala from trees of the Geisha variety and processed by a refined version of the natural or dried-in-the-fruit method. Notes: Produced at Finca La Hermosa by Max and Claudia Perez from trees of the famous Gesha (also spelled Geisha) variety and processed by the traditional washed method. Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Balanced, roundly floral- and citrus-toned. Lime, red apple, freesia, almond in aroma and cup. Effervescently buoyant and bright in structure, lightly syrupy in mouthfeel. The herb-toned flowers and citrus ring on in a quiet but long finish.
Notes: A blend of coffees from trees of the Geisha variety grown on Finca Bella Vista and Finca Carmona in the Antigua growing region of Guatemala by Luis Pedro Zelaya. Processed by the traditional washed method. Kafe Coffee Roastery is a specialty roaster based in Zhubei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Exceptionally sweet, lushly fruit-toned. Pistachio, ripe strawberry, baking chocolate, cedar, marjoram in aroma and cup. Juicy in structure; plush in mouthfeel. Fruit floods the short finish, rings on in the long.
Notes: Produced by farmer Don Gerson on Finca San Rafael in the mountains of the Huehuetenango growing region, Guatemala. From trees of the famous Gesha (also spelled Geisha) variety and processed by the natural or dried-in-the-fruit method. Bonlife Coffee Roasters is a woman-owned specialty roaster in Cleveland, Tennessee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Crisp, low-toned, chocolaty. Baking chocolate, orange, toasted coconut, wisteria, macadamia nut in aroma and cup. Bittersweet in structure, plush in mouthfeel. Chocolate takes over in the finish, nicely complicated by orange and flowers.
Notes: Produced on one or more of the Finca Bella Carmona farms in the celebrated Antigua growing region of Guatemala by Luis Pedro Zelaya from trees of the Bourbon and Caturra cultivars. Handlebar Coffee was founded in Santa Barbara, California, in 2011 by two former professional cyclists, and the couple now operates two thriving

Coffee Origin: Rabinal Municipality, Baja Verapaz Department, Guatemala
Blind Assessment: Gently bright, balanced, classic. Raspberry, sweet cocoa, magnolia, cashew butter, orange zest in aroma and cup. Sweetly bright and gently lively in structure; plush in mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates to orange and cocoa in a quiet but vibrant finish.
Notes: This exciting coffee was selected as the No. 14 coffee on

Blind Assessment: Roundly bright, sweet. Black cherry, tangerine, cashew, cocoa powder, pear in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet-tart in structure; satiny in mouthfeel. Cashew and cocoa powder carry into the cleanly balanced finish.
Notes: Produced by farmer Porfirio Velasquez on his 7-acre farm in the Huehuetenango growing region from trees of the Bourbon, Caturra and Sarchimor varieties. Certified organic, and processed by the traditional washed method. Notes: Produced by Juan Diego de la Cerda of Finca El Socorro entirely of the Laurina variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method. Laurina, also called Bourbon Pointu, is a rare selection of Bourbon with small, pointed beans, small, conical trees and naturally low caffeine content. Willoughby’s Coffee & Tea is a pioneer specialty coffee roaster established in the early 1980s that has gracefully and successfully moved with the times and now offers a menu of extremely refined small-lot, single-origin coffees. Blind Assessment: Crisp, sweet, delicate. Fir, cocoa, macadamia, jasmine, lemon in aroma and cup. Sweetly bright and high-toned in structure, silky mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a quiet finish.
Notes: Produced at Finca Vista Hermosa by the family of Edwin Martinez from trees of the rare Marago-Pache variety, a cross between the very large-beaned Maragogype and Pache, a compact-growing Typica mutant. Processed by the traditional washed method. Torque Coffee has an unusual business model that promises 20 percent of the retail value of each coffee to its producer. Visit

Blind Assessment: Exceptionally sweet, delicately tart. Lychee, sticky rice, bergamot, sandalwood, lemon verbena in aroma and cup. Citrusy-bright acidity; creamy mouthfeel. Richly bittersweet, long finish with notes of bergamot and lychee with sandalwood undertones.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of local landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the honey method, in which some of the fruit flesh is left on the beans during the drying process. Coffee Name: Finca La Reserva Colombia Gesha Honey
Blind Assessment: Watermelon candy, magnolia, graphite, almond blossom, dark chocolate in aroma and cup. High-toned, balanced acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Crisp, chocolaty finish supported by notes of watermelon candy and magnolia.
Notes: Produced by Juan Felipe of Finca La Reserva, entirely of the Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic honey method, in which some of the fruit flesh is left on the beans during the drying process, which, in this case, was preceded by a 96-hour fermentation in hermetically sealed vessels. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Blind Assessment: Elegantly fruit-centered, richly aromatic. Plum confit, wild honey, frangipane, clove, lavender in aroma and cup. Complex, bittersweet structure with juicy acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Long, mesmerizing finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 7 coffee on

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, complex, floral-toned. Amber, lime zest, narcissus, Nutella, cedar in aroma and cup. Bittersweet structure with balanced, juicy acidity; very smooth, silky mouthfeel. Amber and narcissus notes predominate in the long-lasting finish, supported by nutty chocolate.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers and processed by Faysel Abdosh, from trees of the 774110 and 74158 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying) and an extended 72-hour fermentation period.
