JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, spice-toned. Cashew butter, pomelo, black sage, green apple, fine musk in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; velvety mouthfeel. Exceptionally harmonious, integrated finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers around the Murundo Washing Station, entirely of the Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Coffee Name: Guatemala Natural Finca El General Bourbon/Catuai
Blind Assessment: Balanced, sweetly nutty, gently tart. Pomegranate, hazelnut, baking chocolate, cedar, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Quiet finish settles into notes of baking chocolate and pomegranate.
Notes: Produced at Finca El General, from trees of the Bourbon and Catuai varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Guji Hambella Strawberry Truffles Kurume G1 Natural
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Richly bittersweet. Candied walnut, black sage, sesame, palm sugar, dried persimmon in aroma and cup. Delicately rich, tart acidity; vibrant, silky mouthfeel. Nut-toned finish with undertones of black sage.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from local heirloom varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). 1980 Cafe is a Tainan City, Taiwan-based specialty coffee roaster. Visit

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Guji Uraga Pear Gummies G1 Washed
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Cocoa-toned, sweetly fermenty. Orange zest, cocoa nib, grappa barrel, pink peppercorn, lilac in aroma and cup. Zesty, pert acidity; very full, velvety-smooth mouthfeel. Sweetly fermenty, grappa-barrel finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from local heirloom varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and ulp removed before drying). 1980 Cafe is a Tainan City, Taiwan-based specialty coffee roaster. Visit

Coffee Name: Kenya Nyeri Kianjogu AA TOP Washed
Blind Assessment: Bright, juicy, richly sweet-savory. Black currant, shiitake mushroom, amber, lilac, Meyer lemon zest in aroma and cup. High-toned, apple-like acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Citrusy, floral finish.
Notes: Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Bright, vibrant, chocolaty. Dark chocolate, magnolia, red currant, cedar, lemon verbena in aroma and small cup. Crisp, satiny-smooth mouthfeel; chocolaty, citrusy-herbaceous finish. In cappuccino format, rich-toned, chocolaty and floral.
Notes: Evie’s Café, based in Chia-Yi, Taiwan, specializes in fine roasted coffees as well as pourovers and cold brews. Visit the

Coffee Origin: Kiawamururu, Nyeri growing region, south-central Kenya
Blind Assessment: Multi-layered, richly sweet. Black cherry, baking chocolate, magnolia, pink grapefruit zest, oak in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with brisk acidity; syrupy-smooth, vibrant mouthfeel. Pink grapefruit and baking chocolate in the finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Crisply chocolaty, rich-toned. Baking chocolate, caramel, pomegranate, lily, cedar in aroma and small cup. Velvety-smooth mouthfeel. Caramelly, gently tart finish. In cappuccino format, nicely chocolaty with lily and cedar undertones.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the Caturra variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Sweetly nut-toned. Pistachio, baking chocolate, orange zest, agave syrup, nutmeg in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; lightly satiny mouthfeel. Nut-toned finish with hints of orange zest and baking chocolate.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the Bourbon and Caturra varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Multi-layered, richly complex. Pomegranate, dried pineapple, cocoa nib, marjoram, wisteria in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet, fruity acidity; full, creamy-smooth mouthfeel. Long, resonant, flavor-laden finish.
Notes: Produced by Carlos Cerquera of Finca La Esperanza, entirely of the Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying).  Oak & Bond is a specialty retail and wholesale coffee roaster based in Charlotte, North Carolina. The company’s name combines “oak,” a reference to its first coffee, a barrel-aged release, and “bond,” referring to the founders’ happy marriage. For more information, visit

Blind Assessment: Balanced, crisply sweet. Lemon verbena, almond, dark caramel, freesia, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned acidity; full, very satiny mouthfeel. Notes of freesia and almond lead in the sweet finish.
Notes: Produced at Finca Alto Refugio, from trees of the Bourbon, Catuai, Caturra and Typica varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Utopian Coffee is a specialty roaster based in Fort Wayne, Indiana. Visit

Blind Assessment: Deeply chocolaty, floral-toned. Dark chocolate, lilac, hazelnut butter, apricot, tangerine in aroma and cup. Balanced, bright acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The finish leads with notes of lilac and dark chocolate.
Notes: Produced by Wilmar Castillo of Finca Vista Al Bosque, from the Bourbon and Caturra varieties of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Oak & Bond is a specialty retail and wholesale coffee roaster based in Charlotte, North Carolina. The company’s name combines “oak,” a reference to its first coffee, a barrel-aged release, and “bond,” referring to the founders’ happy marriage. For more information, visit

Blind Assessment: Delicately sweet-savory. Date, hop flowers, agave syrup, tamarind, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet-savory acidity; velvety-smooth mouthfeel. Finish centers around notes of date and tamarind with undertones of fir.
Notes: Comprised of the SL28 and SL34 varieties of Arabica, and purchased from C. Dorman in Nairobi, who sources green coffee from Kenya producers. Heat Coffee is a nano-roaster in Taipei, Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest-quality coffee. Visit the

Blind Assessment: Sweetly nut-toned, citrusy. Orange zest, hazelnut, baking chocolate, lily, oak in aroma and cup. High-toned, juicy acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of baking chocolate and cedar.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Ethiopia, Kenya and Brazil. Heat Coffee is a nano-roaster in Taipei, Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest-quality coffee. Visit the

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly tart, richly chocolaty. Cocoa powder, Fig Newton, black cherry, cedar, hazelnut in aroma and small cup. Crisp, sattiny mouthfeel; cocoa-toned, nutty finish. In cappuccino format, richly sweet and fruit-driven.
Notes: A blend of three coffees: a natural-processed Brazil, a washed Costa Rica and a natural-processed Ethiopia, roasted for both brewed and espresso applications. Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious, high-quality coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Crisply chocolaty, sweetly citrusy. Dark chocolate, pink grapefruit zest, tamarind, fresh-cut oak, magnolia in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolaty, floral-toned finish.
Notes: A blend of three coffees: a natural-processed Brazil, a washed Costa Rica and a natural-processed Ethiopia, roasted for both brewed and espresso applications. Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious, high-quality coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Co-taster John DiRuocco and Ken both found a sweetly tangy intrigue animating this plush, satiny bodied espresso, and rewarded it with 95s. Ken called it rich pistachio; John favored musky, mango-like tropical fruit. For both tasters, the pistachio/mango notes impressively sweetened and moved forward in three parts milk.
Notes: Produced by Shady & Elias Bayter of El Vergel Estate, entirely of the Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by the carbonic maceration natural method, which involves fermenting whole coffee fruit inside a sealed container that has been flushed with CO2, then drying the coffee in the whole fruit. Imported by Forest Coffee. Big Shoulders Coffee is a Chicago artisan roaster that emphasizes a fresh-roasted, no-nonsense approach to fine coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Sweet grapefruit and orange blossom notes shimmer inside a deeply expressed chocolate in aroma and cup. Velvety mouthfeel. Ken and co-taster John DiRuocco shared parallel descriptors and the same 95-point enthusiasm for this poised, resonantly finishing espresso. Floral-toned chocolate with a continued grapefruit hint graces three parts milk.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez entirely of the Colombia variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic kōji method, in which the coffee fruit is first sterilized and then fermented in a bio-reactor and inoculated with a selection of Japanese kōji (Aspergillus oryzae). This mold species breaks down starch into simple sugars and is commonly used in the production of soy sauce, miso, sake and shōchū

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. This was Ken’s favorite in the tasting; he had it at 96 with a 10 for aroma. Co-taster John DiRuocco was a bit less enthusiastic at 94. The difference may have been their reading of the striking floral herb notes. Ken experienced them as exhilarating sweet lavender while John read them as a pleasant but drier eucalyptus. But both overall admired this sweetly citrusy, walnut-toned, brightly chocolaty espresso whose character resonates through the finish and retains character impressively in three parts milk.
Notes: Produced by Wilson Alva of Finca Sierra Morena, entirely of the Pink Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin, pulp and flesh all removed before drying). Imported by Coffee Quest. Wonderstate Coffee, formerly Kickapoo Coffee, is an award-winning roaster based in rural Wisconsin known for its commitment to guaranteeing higher pay for farmers and operating the country’s first 100% solar-powered roastery. Visit

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Growers Reserve Gesha Village Gaylee Special Fermentation
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Resonant, layered berry (blueberry, raspberry), vanilla-toned flowers, papaya, a hint of cinnamon jostle in aroma and in the cup, where aromatics are suspended in a layered structure of complex bitter, sweet, tart and savory tastes. Ken (94) liked this velvety, viscous espresso a bit better than co-taster John DiRuocco (93). The complexity consolidates a bit in three parts milk, where flavor settles in with quiet certainty around a pronounced chocolate.
Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It was processed by a proprietary method described as “semi-anaerobic honey.” AOI Coffee is a specialty roaster and cafe in Taiping, Taichung, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Anaerobic Washed G1 Wild Rose S.O. Sidamo
Coffee Origin: Bensa District, Sidamo growing region, Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Ripe, berryish fruit hints at brandy in this lush yet tartly dry espresso that reveals its rounder chocolate side in the cup. Ken (93) decided to like its intensity and tart fruit sweetness. Co-cupper John DiRuocco went more decisively to the bright side at 94. Convincing in three parts milk: crisp chocolate with a juicy, fruit-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from local Ethiopian landrace varieties of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic washed method, in which, after skin and pulp removal, fermentation takes place in a hermetically sealed vessel before the beans are washed and dried. Imported into Taiwan by Wells Coffee. Balmy Day Coffee Office is a specialty nano-roastery based in Taoyuan, Taiwan. For more information, visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. In the aroma, lush, chocolaty fruit (maraschino cherry, ripe orange) transforms to a bright, floral citrus in the cup, slightly drying but sweet. Co-taster John DiRuocco (94) felt that the entire package came together nicely, with “nice high notes balanced by chocolate undertones, acidity by body.” Ken had less conviction in regard to coherence, but he too characterized the mouthfeel as full and plush, the cup impressive, and seconded John’s 94. Both particularly praised the coffee in three parts milk, where lemon, chocolate and cherry tendencies played nicely.
Notes: Produced at Finca Buenavista, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the double-anaerobic washed method,

Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Ken (94) found this anaerobic natural Kona luxurious with deep floral notes and softly subtle chocolate and orange. Co-taster John DiRuocco (93) concurred but was bothered by what he regarded as a very slight overripe edge to the fruit. Both found the mouthfeel medium in weight but impressively plush in texture, and the shot in three parts milk delicately complex with flowers, fruit and chocolate working in layered coherence.
Notes: A single-farm blend of coffees grown, processed and roasted at Hula Daddy. Processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which the whole fruit is fermented with limited oxygen before it is dried. Hula Daddy is a boutique coffee producer with farms at the 1,400- and 2,500-foot levels of the Mount Hualalai volcano near the northern end of the Kona growing district, five minutes above the town of Kailua-Kona. Visit

Coffee Name: El Salvador Finca Loma La Gloria Natural Process “Unicorn Lot”
Coffee Origin: El Bálsamo Quetzaltepec growing region, El Salvador
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Chocolate, mango and sweet lime animate this satiny bodied espresso. Impressive stone-fruit sweetness is complicated by an engaging resiny edge co-taster John DiRuocco (94) and Ken (93) both associated with mango. Mango and chocolate crisply and sweetly persist in three parts milk.
Notes: This outstanding coffee was selected as the No. 27 coffee on

Coffee Name: Colombia El Diviso Nestor Lasso Sidra Anaerobic Washed
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Lots of flowers with an herby edge—lavender, jasmine, orange blossom, cilantro—cushion on milk chocolate in this bright, light-footed espresso. Both co-taster John DiRuocco and Ken read this high-toned but resonant espresso in about the same terms with parallel ratings of 94. Resolves to an orangy, floral caramel in three parts milk.
Notes: Produced by Nestor Lasso of Finca El Diviso, entirely of the Sidra variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic washed method, in which, after skin and pulp removal, fermentation takes place in a hermetically sealed vessel before the beans are washed and dried. OLI Cafe Roaster is a specialty coffee roaster based in Dali, Taichung, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Name: Colombia Red Fruits Campo Hermosa Edwin Noreña
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Co-taster John DiRuocco (95) was particularly impressed by the lavish sweetness and fruit of this elaborately anaerobic-processed coffee from Colombian processing innovator Edwin Noreña. John found the well-structured and clean-finishing character sufficient to contain and balance the aromatic fireworks. Ken (92), on the other hand, found the sweetness and fruit a bit too intense and candy-like, though he found compensating value in underlying musk and sandalwood tendencies. Both tasters admired the coffee in three parts milk, which rounded and diluted the intensely sweet fruit.
Notes: Produced by Edwin Noreña of Finca Campo Hermosa, entirely of the Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by a complex version of carbonic maceration. Whole coffee fruit is

Coffee Name: Juru Rwanda Rulindo Red Bourbon Honey
Coffee Origin: Cyinzuzi Sector, Rulindo District, Northern Province, Rwanda
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Co-taster John DiRuocco (94) liked this coffee (“brightly orange and juicy, sweet, jasmine and stone fruit”) a bit better than Ken did (93), who nevertheless concurred with John’s descriptors and added dark chocolate and molasses. Both found the mouthfeel plush and satiny. In three parts milk, the shot proved delicate yet substantial, with an animated, light-footed chocolate.
Notes: Produced by Juru Coffee at the Burega, Buyoga and Cyinzuzi farms, entirely of the Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the honey method (skins and attached pulp are removed, but some fruit flesh is left on the beans during drying). Imported by Linking Coffee. MK Coffee Roasters, a short walk from the Shulin train station in New Taipei City, specializes in high-quality roasted beans to take home and expertly brewed coffees to enjoy in the café. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Co-taster John DiRuocco (94) found spicy fruit, orange water and vanilla-like flowers in aroma and cup; Ken (93) concurred and added sweet chocolate and almonds. Altogether a silky textured, lively espresso. The aromatic intricacy consolidates a bit in three parts milk, and the familiar chocolate and almondy nut move forward.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez, entirely of the Castillo variety of Arabica, and processed by the double-anaerobic thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with a strain of Lactobacillus for 24 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit

Coffee Origin: Dame Debaye washing station, Guji growing region, south-central Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Ken intensely admired this classic washed profile for its round brightness, plum-toned fruit, rose-toned flowers, and chocolaty and cedary balance, rating it 95. For co-taster John DiRuocco, the profile was pleasing but one-dimensional, though he rewarded the smooth mouthfeel, citrusy brightness and clean balance with a 92. Ken found the floral chocolate and cedary base particularly impressive in three parts milk.
Notes: Grown by smallholding farmers in the vicinity of Dame Debaye washing station, from selections of landrace Ethiopian tree varieties, and processed by the traditional washed method. Exported by Sibu Coffee and imported by Sucafina. Speckled Ax is a roaster based in Portland, Maine, specializing in high-quality certified organic and small-lot coffees. The company roasts in a vintage wood-fired Petroncini roaster with the goal of highlighting each coffee’s best attributes. Visit

Coffee Name: Colombia Red Honey Geisha Campo Hermoso
Blind Assessment: Elegantly fruit-forward, richly aromatic. Wild strawberry, cocoa nib, lemon verbena, amber, narcissus in aroma and cup. Balanced, juicy acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Long, resonant, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Produced by Edwin Noreña of Finca Campo Hermoso, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the red honey method, in which much of the fruit flesh is left on the beans during the drying process. Bear Lake Coffee Co., a B Corp-certified coffeehouse and roastery located in Barronett, Wisconsin, is committed to sustainability through its Coffee with a Purpose™ initiative, which ensures that farmers receive compensation well above the Fairtrade Premium for their exceptional small-batch coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Complex, richly sweet-tart. Pomegranate, pineapple kefir, cocoa nib, freesia, cedar in aroma and cup. Tart-leaning structure with bright, bright acidity; very full, satiny mouthfeel. Tangy finish with notes of cocoa nib and pineapple kefir.
Notes: Produced by Faysel Yonis, from trees of local heirloom varieties of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method (whole coffee fruit is fermented with limited oxygen before drying) at the Gara Agena Washing Station. Bear Lake Coffee Co., a B Corp-certified coffeehouse and roastery located in Barronett, Wisconsin, is committed to sustainability through its Coffee with a Purpose™ initiative, which ensures that farmers receive compensation well above the Fairtrade Premium for their exceptional small-batch coffee. Visit

Coffee Name: El Salvador Finca San Antonio Pacas Natural
Coffee Origin: Apaneca Illamatepec growing region, Juayúa, El Salvador
Blind Assessment: Balanced, deep-toned. Black cherry, salted caramel, hop flowers, lemon balm, cocoa powder in aroma and cup. Sparkling acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. In the finish, salted caramel and black cherry harmonize.
Notes: Produced by the Pola Family of Finca San Antonio, entirely of the Pacas variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Bear Lake Coffee Co., a B Corp-certified coffeehouse and roastery located in Barronett, Wisconsin, is committed to sustainability through its Coffee with a Purpose™ initiative, which ensures that farmers receive compensation well above the Fairtrade Premium for their exceptional small-batch coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Crisply sweet-savory, deep-toned. Baking chocolate, date, hazelnut, gardenia, thyme in aroma and small cup. Full, velvety mouthfeel; chocolaty, sweetly nut-toned finish. In cappuccino format, notes of baking chocolate and hazelnut take center stage, supported by gardenia and thyme.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Costa Rica, El Salvador and Ethiopia, roasted for espresso applications. Bear Lake Coffee Co., a B Corp-certified coffeehouse and roastery located in Barronett, Wisconsin, is committed to sustainability through its Coffee with a Purpose™ initiative, which ensures that farmers receive compensation well above the Fairtrade Premium for their exceptional small-batch coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Floral-toned, super-sweet. Wisteria, cocoa nib, rambutan, black sage, salted caramel in aroma and cup. Malic (apple-like) acidity; plush, viscous mouthfeel. Concentrated finish that carries through on the promise of the cup.
Notes: Produced at Finca Granito de Oro, entirely of the Caturra Chiroso variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Founded in 2013, modcup coffee focuses on fresh roasting and distinctive natural-processed coffees. Visit

Coffee Name: Kona SL 34 Anaerobic Washed Kona Rainforest
Coffee Origin: South Kona, Big Island of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Fruit-driven, brightly sweet. Nectarine, black cherry, magnolia, pomelo, cedar in aroma and cup. Gently bright, sweetly tart acidity; crsip, dry-vermouth-like body. Resonant, harmonious, integrated finish.
Notes: Produced at the organic-certified Kona Rainforest Farm, entirely of the SL34 variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic washed method, with the addition of an organic yeast strain (developed in collaboration with Miguel Meza) to the fermentation. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit

Blind Assessment: Richly aromatic, multi-layered, deeply sweet. Fruit Loops cereal, pineapple kefir, cocoa nib, black sage, agave nectar in aroma and cup. Bright, balanced acidity; plush, very syrupy mouthfeel. Long finish centered around notes of Fruit Loops and cocoa nib.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez of Granja Paraiso 92, entirely of the Yellow Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with a strain of Lactobacillus for 24 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Afterward, the washed parchment coffee is rapidly dried with an in-house designed Eco-Enigma dehumidifying dryer to avoid over-oxidation or continued fermentation. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Nuanced, multi-layered, high-toned. Bergamot, strawberry guava, cocoa nib, almond butter, freesia in aroma and small cup. Plush, syrupy mouthfeel; long, satiating finish. In three parts milk, notes of freesia and cocoa nib are amplified, with undertones of strawberry guava, almond and bergamot.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers and processed by Faysel Abdosh, from trees of the 774110 and 74158 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying) and an extended 72-hour fermentation period. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Blind Assessment: Sweetly spice-toned, delicately aromatic. Ginger blossom, clove, narcissus, cocoa nib, goji berry in aroma and cup. Gently bright, balanced acidity; vibrant, silky mouthfeel. Crisp, cocoa-toned finish supported by notes of ginger blossom and clove.
Notes: Produced by the Guerrero, Sepulveda and Trejos families, from trees of the Castillo, Caturra and Colombia varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Rusty Dog Coffee is a Madison, Wisconsin-based specialty coffee roaster. Visit

Coffee Origin: Ka‘ū growing district, Big Island of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Bright, balanced, richly sweet. Dark chocolate, narcissus, Meyer lemon, thyme, apricot in aroma and cup. Juicy-bright acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Dark chocolate is the throughline in the satisfying finish.
Notes: This 100% Ka’u coffee was developed by Lorie Obra of Rusty’s, one of Ka‘ū’s best-known and most celebrated farms. Produced from trees of the Typica variety of Arabica and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Very fruity and richly chocolaty. Black cherry, guava, dark chocolate, tangerine zest, cedar in aroma and small cup. Crisp, satiny mouthfeel; fruity, chocolaty finish. In three parts milk, chocolaty-sweet and invigoratingly tart.
Notes: Produced by Felipe Arcila of Jardines del Eden, entirely of the Caturra variety of Arabica, and processed by an experimental method in which the whole cherries are submerged in water for 48 hours before processing by the anaerobic natural method, where the whole cherries are fermented in an oxygen-free environment before being dried. Regent strives to deliver coffee with care and purpose. Visit

Coffee Origin: Kona and Kaʻū, Big Island of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Richly chocolaty, gently spice-toned. Dark chocolate, clove, almond butter, pink grapefruit zest, date in aroma and small cup. Creamy-smooth mouthfeel; crisply chocolaty finish with undertones of pink grapefruit zest and clove. In cappuccino format, the perfect drink for baked goods with loads of butter and baking spices.
Notes: A blend of Hawaiian coffees from the regions of Kona and Kaʻū, both on the Big Island. Big Island Coffee Roasters is an award-winning coffee roaster operated with hands-on passion by Kelleigh Stewart and Brandon von Damitz. Visit

Coffee Name: Colombia Thermal Shock Double Anaerobic Granja Paraiso Orange Gesha
Blind Assessment: Elegantly berry-toned, dessert-like. Mulberry, candycap mushroom amber, apricot nectar, dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet-savory acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Harmonious, integrated, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez, entirely of the Orange Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the double-anaerobic thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with a strain of Lactobacillus for 24 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit

Coffee Name: Kenya Nyeri Hill Estate AA Top Espresso
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Rich-toned, deeply sweet-savory. Black currant, pomegranate, hop flowers, dark chocolate, magnolia, cedar in aroma and small cup. Crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel; intense, concentrated finish rife with notes of black currant, magnolia and dark chocolate. In cappuccino format, dark chocolate notes are amplified, as are magnolia and black currant.
Notes: Produced at Nyeri Hill Estate, from trees of the SL28, SL34 and Riuru 11 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Juicy, lithe, high-toned. Lychee, passionfruit, sandalwood, cocoa nib, marjoram in aroma and cup. Sparkling acidity; crisp, lushly satiny mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned tropical fruit in the finish.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which the whole fruit is fermented in an oxygen-free environment before being dried. the Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Brightly sweet, rich-toned. Red currant, agave syrup, lemon verbena, dark chocolate, cedar in aroma and cup. Juicy, lively acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Sweetly herbaceous finish supported by notes of dark chocolate and cedar.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of the Barichu Cooperative Society, from trees of the SL28, SL34, K7 and Ruiru 11 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Located in southwestern Colorado, Durango Coffee lays claim to a rich coffee history that dates to 1986. Its motto is “Tough Town, Great Coffee.” Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Rich, deep, sweetly nutty. Hazelnut butter, tamarind, jasmine, dark chocolate, cedar in aroma and small cup. Crisp, velvety-smooth mouthfeel; nutty, chocolaty finish. In cappuccino format, Nutella-like in its marriage of chocolate and hazelnut notes.
Notes: Produced by the Ortega family of Finca La Merced, entirely of the Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying).

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Deep-toned, crisply chocolaty. Baking chocolate, hazelnut, date, gardenia, oak in aroma and small cup. Full, creamy mouthfeel; sweetly nut-toned, wood-framed finish. In cappuccino format, notes of baking chocolate and hazelnut are supported by oak.
Notes: A blend of coffees from four origins — Colombia, Brazil, Guatemala and Ethiopia — roasted for espresso applications. AKA Coffee is a specialty nano-roaster based in Taiwan. Visit AKA Coffee's

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Richly aromatic, brightly sweet-tart. Dark chocolate, black cherry, tamarind, cedar, finger lime in aroma and small cup. Full, creamy mouthfeel; richly chocolaty, tart-leaning finish. In cappuccino format, dark chocolate and black cherry notes carry the profile, with support from finger lime and cedar.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the Ateng, Bor Bor, Catimor and Timor varieties of Arabica, and processed at Iwannitosa Putra’s Putra Gayo wet mill by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Coffee Origin: Kenya; Guatemala; Brazil; Nicaragua; Honduras; Indonesia
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly nut-toned, earthy and caramelly. Dark caramel, almond, pipe tobacco, date, oak in aroma and small cup. Full, syrupy mouthfeel; gently drying, wood-framed finish. In cappuccino-scaled milk, caramel is front and center, supported by notes of pipe tobacco and date.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Kenya, Guatemala, Brazil, Nicaragua, Honduras and Indonesia, roasted for espresso applications. Fellow Coffee is a specialty roaster based in Taipei, Taiwan. Email

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly nutty, invitingly crisp. Cashew butter, cocoa powder, golden raisin, cedar, orange zest in aroma and small cup. Velvety-smooth mouthfeel; finish consolidates to notes of cocoa powder and cashew. In three parts milk, nut tones further sweeten and cocoa powder is also amplified.
Notes: A blend of washed coffees from Kenya, India and Guatemala, roasted for espresso applications. Interlude Coffee Roasters is a specialty roaster based in Taipei, Taiwan. Email

Blind Assessment: Brightly sweet, gently tart. Cocoa nib, pink peppercorn, freesia, apricot, almond in aroma and cup. Juicy, vibrant acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Notes of pink peppercorn and freesia are supported by cocoa nib in the long finish.
Notes: Produced at Finca El Silencio, entirely of the Pink Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). MK Coffee Roasters, a short walk from the Shulin train station in New Taipei City, specializes in high-quality roasted beans to take home and expertly brewed coffees to enjoy in the café. Visit

Blind Assessment: Crisply chocolaty, richly bittersweet. Baking chocolate, lime zest, magnolia, date, cedar in aroma and cup. Gentle, sweet-toned acidity; dry vermouth-like mouthfeel. Baking chocolate and lime zest lead in the finish, with undertones of magnolia.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Colombia, Ethiopia and Honduras, all washed-process. Caffè Luxxe is an Italian-inflected artisan roaster and retailer that emphasizes both its coffee knowledge and precision and its straightforward lack of pretension. Visit

Blind Assessment: Nuanced, multi-layered fruit-forward. Bergamot, apricot nectar, star jasmine, lemon balm, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Complex, juicy acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Long-lasting finish that carries over all the flavor notes from the cup.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica. Processed by the kōji method, in which the coffee fruit is first sterilized and then fermented in a bio-reactor and inoculated with a selection of Japanese kōji (Aspergillus oryzae). This mold species breaks down starch into simple sugars and is commonly used in the production of soy sauce, miso, sake and shōchū

Blind Assessment: Deeply sweet-savory. Mulberry, cocoa nib, thyme, cedar, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Sweetly herbaceous finish supported by cocoa nib and mulberry.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the SL28 and SL34 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Bargain Cafe is a specialty coffee roaster in Taitung, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Honey Peach of Floral Language
Blind Assessment: Delicately high-toned. Nectarine, honey, narcissus, cocoa nib, tangerine zest in aroma and cup. Gently bright, juicy acidity; crisp, silky mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of cocoa nib and nectarine.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of local heirloom varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Bargain Cafe is a specialty coffee roaster in Taitung, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly nut-toned, gently fruity. Cashew butter, pomegranate, orange zest, baking chocolate, oak in aroma and small cup. Velvety-smooth mouthfeel; crisp, nutty finish. In cappuccino-scaled milk, pomegranate notes predominate, supported by creamy cashew tones.
Notes: A blend of three coffees: a natural-processed Brazil, a washed India and a natural-processed Ethiopia, roasted for espresso applications. Green Stone Coffee is a woman-owned artisan roastery in Taipei, Taiwan founded in 2016 and specializing in sourcing distinctive coffees that express their individual terroirs. Visit

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Guji Hambela Natural Tsigered G1
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: High-toned, crisply fruity. Blueberry, tamarind, baking chocolate, pink peppercorn, freesia in aroma and cup. Briskly tart acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of blueberry and tamarind with undertones of pink peppercorn.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of local heirloom varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Cafe Choisi is a specialty coffee roaster based in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Deep-toned, richly sweet. Dark chocolate, clove, apricot, caramel, cedar in aroma and cup. Bright, balanced acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. Chocolaty, spice-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the Ateng, Bor Bor, Catimor and Timor varieties of Arabica, and processed at Iwannitosa Putra’s Putra Gayo wet mill by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Heidenröslein Anaerobic Washed G1
Coffee Origin: Bensa District, Sidamo growing region, Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Deeply aromatic, complex. Bergamot, mulberry, tea rose, cinnamon, amber in aroma and cup. Delicately sweet-tart acidity; crisp, silky-smooth mouthfeel. Long, resonant, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of local heirloom varieties of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic washed method, in which the fermentation step occurs in a hermetically sealed vessel before the beans are washed and dried. Kafe Coffee Roastery is a specialty roaster based in Zhubei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Cocoa-toned, sweetly herbaceous. Cocoa nib, nectarine, lemon verbena, agave syrup, cedar in aroma and cup. Balanced, juicy acidity; silky-smooth mouthfeel. Citrusy finish supported by cocoa nib and cedar.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers of the Kimaratia Farmers Cooperative Society, from trees of the SL28, SL34 and Ruiri 11 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Utopian Coffee is a specialty roaster based in Fort Wayne, Indiana. Visit

Blind Assessment: Brightly sweet-tart, fruit-toned. Cocoa nib, dried pineapple, magnolia, sage, sweet cream in aroma and cup. Sweetly brisk acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The quiet finish consolidates to cocoa nib and cedar. With pineapple undertones.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the indigenous Kurume landrace variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit).

Blind Assessment: Richly fruit- and floral-toned. Lychee, wisteria, cocoa nib, pineapple taffy, thyme in aroma and cup. Juicy-bright acidity; crisp, silky mouthfeel. Cocoa-driven finish with pretty fruit and floral undertones.
Notes: Produced at Finca La Julia, entirely of the Castillo variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural fermentation method, in which whole fruit is fermented with limited oxygen before being dried. A Little Happiness is a small specialty coffee roaster based in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit the company’s

Blind Assessment: Delicately sweet, berry-toned. Strawberry, baking chocolate, pecan, fir, salted caramel in aroma and cup. Gently brisk acidity; lightly satiny mouthfeel. Crisp, quiet finish, caramelly and nutty.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers who are members of a “subak abian,” or collective, from trees of the Bourbon, S795, USDA 762, Typica and Catimor varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). City Boy Coffee is a specialty roaster based in Long Island City, New York. Visit

Coffee Origin: Agaro Gera, Jimma Zone, Oromia State, Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Delicately sweet-tart, fruit-toned. Pluot, pomelo, pink peppercorn, cocoa nib, freesia in aroma and cup. Sweetly bright with citrusy acidity; very satiny, buoyant mouthfeel. Finish centers around notes of cocoa nib and pomelo.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers under the direction of Kata Muduga and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Souvenir Coffee, based in Berkeley, California, goes by the motto, “People first, then coffee.”

Blind Assessment: Crisply chocolaty, deep-toned. Baking chocolate, date, hazelnut, brown sugar, cedar in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Finish centers around notes of baking chocolate and hazelnut with cedar undertones.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Brazil and Southeast Asia. Souvenir Coffee, based in Berkeley, California, goes by the motto, “People first, then coffee.” Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Richly sweet, multi-layered. Chocolate fudge, date, graham cracker, cedar in aroma and small cup. Creamy-smooth mouthfeel; chocolaty, richly sweet finish. In cappuccino format, crisply sweet date harmonizes with chocolate fudge for a dessert-like profile.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Guatemala, Honduras and Colombia, roasted for espresso applications. Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Black Honey Guji Wate Lot Tabby
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Floral-toned, fruity. Raspberry jam, narcissus, dark chocolate, hazelnut, cedar in aroma and cup. Balanced, sweet-tart acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Raspberry and dark chocolate lead in the long finish, supported by hints of narcissus.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from local heirloom varieties of Arabica, and processed by the black honey method, in which much of the fruit flesh is left on the bean during the dying process. Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Crisply cocoa-toned, richly floral. Cocoa nib, gardenia, pomegranate, fresh-cut oak, molasses in aroma and small cup. Satiny-smooth mouthfeel; cocoa- and floral-toned finish. In three parts milk, the through line is cocoa nib with undertone of gardenia and oak.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Guatemala, Ethiopia and Colombia roasted for espresso applications. Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit

Coffee Name: Finca Vista Hermosa Edwin’s Reserve Guatemala
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, balanced, deep. Dark chocolate, yellow plum, agave syrup, lemon verbena, amber in aroma and cup. Delicately bright acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Flavor-saturated finish centers around notes of dark chocolate and amber.
Notes: Produced by Edward Martinez of Finca Vista Hermosa, from trees of the Caturra, Catuai and Bourbon varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Imported by Onyx Coffee. Torque Coffee has a unique business model that promises 20 percent of the retail value of each coffee to its producer. Visit

Coffee Name: Costa Rica Las Lajas Perla Negra
Coffee Origin: Sabanilla de Alajuela growing region, Costa Rica
Blind Assessment: Richly fruity, complex. Wild strawberry, cocoa nib, lemon verbena, honeysuckle, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with bright, vibrant acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The long, lingering finish centers around notes of wild strawberry and honeysuckle with undertones of sandalwood.
Notes: This outstanding coffee was selected as the No. 24 coffee on

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Richly chocolaty, floral-toned. Chocolate fudge, pomegranate, narcissus, tangerine zest, gently scorched cedar in aroma and small cup. Tannic, syrupy mouthfeel; crisply chocolaty finish. In cappuccino format, both dark chocolate and narcissus are amplified, backed by tart pomegranate.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of the Kibugu Farmer's Cooperative Society, from trees of the SL28 and SL34 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). GK Coffee is a nano-roastery in Yilan, Taiwan, that offers both retail and wholesale coffee. For more information, visit

Blind Assessment: Complex, multi-layered, deep-toned. Red currant, cocoa nib, tangerine, fresh-cut oak, marjoram in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy structure with phosphoric (cola-like) acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthfeel. Resonant finish centered around notes of red currant and cocoa nib.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the SL28 and SL34 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying) at the Kagunyu Washing Station. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Blind Assessment: Elegantly fruity, tropical leaning. Pineapple, lychee, baking chocolate, pomelo, redwood in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet-tart acidity; crisp, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Fruit-toned finish with hints of baking chocolate.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez of Granja Paraiso 92, entirely of the Chiroso variety of Arabica, and processed by the thermal shock method, in which the coffee fruit, after having been first sanitized with ozone, undergoes two stages of fermentation. First, the whole cherries are submerged under water for 48 hours, then the beans are pulped and fermented with a strain of Lactobacillus for 24 hours. After fermentation, the beans are given a “thermal shock” using hot and cold rinses to help the beans absorb the fermentation metabolites and halt any further fermentation. Afterward, the washed parchment coffee is rapidly dried with an in-house designed Eco-Enigma dehumidifying dryer to avoid over-oxidation or continued fermentation. Big Shoulders Coffee is a Chicago artisan roaster that emphasizes a fresh-roasted, no-nonsense approach to fine coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Crisply chocolaty, deeply sweet. Dark chocolate, rhododendron, pie cherry, lemon-thyme, fresh-cut oak in aroma and small cup. Very full, creamy-smooth mouthfeel; chocolaty, sweetly herbaceous finish. In cappuccino format, dark chocolate and rhododendron notes ramp up, while tart fruit and sweet herbs take a supporting role.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the Caturra, Colombia and Castillo varieties of Arabica, and process by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Blind Assessment: Crisp, vibrantly sweet. Wild honey, dried apricot, cocoa nib, pink grapefruit zest, wisteria in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with brisk acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned finish with notes of dried apricot and pink grapefruit zest.
Notes: Produced at Finca La Rivense’s La Guaca Estate, from trees of the Red Catuai variety of Arabica, and processed by the honey method (coffee fruit is pulped or skinned but dried in the fruit flesh). Kapi Dow is a small specialty coffee roaster in Taichung, Taiwan. Visit the

Blind Assessment: Berry-toned, floral. Blackberry, narcissus, cocoa nib, lemon balm, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of lemon balm and narcissus with undertones of cedar.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of the Mwirua Farmers Cooperative Society, from trees of the SL28, SL34, Ruiru11 and Batian varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skina dn pilp removed before drying) at its Kariaini Factory. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Blind Assessment: Bright, lively, flavor-intense. Sweet lime, freesia, cocoa nib, pink grapefruit zest, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Juicy, citrusy acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Tart fruit and rich florals carry the long finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the 74110 and 74158 varieties of Arabica, and processed by Catalyst Trade’s proprietary 72-hour extended fermentation, in which traditionally washed coffee is fermented for 72 hours. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “Let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Blind Assessment: Delicately sweet-tart, fruit-toned. Lychee, raspberry, cocoa nib, orange zest, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet, gentle acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Cocoa nib and raspberry notes lead in the pleasing finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of heirloom varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit) at Tsegay Hagos Tesfaye’s Sasaba Washing Station. Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features selections from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit

Blind Assessment: Deep-toned, chocolaty and floral. Dark chocolate, narcissus, gently scorched cedar, almond, date in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Chocolaty, floral-toned finish supported by sweetly smoky cedar notes.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of the Kibugu Farmer's Cooperative Society, from trees of the SL28 and SL34 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). GK Coffee is a nano-roastery in Yilan, Taiwan, that offers both retail and wholesale coffee. For more information, visit

Coffee Name: Colombia Finca Milan Washed Nitro Caturra
Blind Assessment: Delicately sweet, richly perfumed. Watermelon candy, lychee, magnolia, almond butter, black sage in aroma and cup. Balanced, bright acidity; very full, creamy mouthfeel. Resonant finish centers notes of watermelon candy, magnolia and almond.
Notes: Produced by Julio Cesar Madrid Tisnes of Finca Milan, entirely of the Caturra variety of Arabica, and processed by nitro-washed method in which ripe cherries undergo embryonic stress. After pulping, the beans are placed in a bioreactor and inoculated with yeast and bacteria for controlled fermentation. Nitrogen is injected to facilitate microbial metabolic processes, closely monitoring temperature, acidity, and Brix throughout. Following bioreactor treatment, the coffee beans are solar-dried to 40% moisture, then transferred to mechanical dryers until they reach 10%-12% moisture. The coffee undergoes a 45-day resting period in the warehouse before hulling. Revel Coffee is a micro-roaster located in Billings, Montana. Its motto: “Quality is paramount – a difference you can revel in.” Visit

Coffee Origin: Wenago district, Gedeo Zone, SNNPR, Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Tropical, multi-layered. Guava, passion fruit, honey, cocoa nib, ginger blossom in aroma and cup. Apple-like (malic) acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Fruity, high-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by Wolde Hirbe, from local heirloom varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit) at the Adame Gorbota Cooperative. Based in southern Oregon, Noble Coffee Roasting is a wholesale and retail roasting company focused on quality, social responsibility and environmental awareness. Visit

Blind Assessment: Balanced, multi-layered. Apricot, lemon blossom, almond butter, willow bark, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Crisply sweet-tart acidity; delicate, satiny mouthfeel. Almond and apricot notes lead the gentle finish.
Notes: Comprised of the Bourbon and Pache varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Deeply sweet, gently herbaceous. Golden raisin, oregano, molasses, oak, onion blossom in aroma and small cup. Lightly satiny mouthfeel; quietly sweet, herbaceous finish. In cappuccino format, balanced and delicately sweet-savory.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Guatemala, Colombia and Brazil, roasted for espresso applications. Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Floral-toned, richly wood-framed. Calla lily, tangerine zest, pink peppercorn, balsa wood, amber in aroma and small cup. Velvety mouthfeel; gently drying, wood-centered finish. In cappuccino-scaled milk, Calla lily and pink peppercorn notes intersect with tangerine zest.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Ethiopia, Colombia and Brazil, roasted for espresso applications. Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Crisply chocolaty, sweetly nutty. Baking chocolate, almond, orange zest, oak, lemon verbena in aroma and small cup. Velvety mouthfeel; almondy finish with undertones of orange zest. In three parts milk, baking chocolate and orange notes play nicely together.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Colombia, Brazil, Nicaragua and Mexico, roasted for espresso applications. Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Name: El Salvador Trifinio Blend Medium Roast
Blind Assessment: Crisply cocoa-toned, sweetly nutty. Cocoa powder, almond, brown sugar, carnation, date in aroma and cup. Balanced, even-keeled acidity; lightly satiny mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of cocoa powder and date.
Notes: Produced by the Galán family, entirely of the Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Trifunio Coffee Company was founded by Fernando Galán, a third-generation coffee farmer, in 2022. Trifinio both grows and roasts its own coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-savory. Date, cashew, agave syrup, cedar, lemon zest in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; velvety-smooth mouthfeel. Sweetly nut-toned finish with hints of lemon zest.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of the Othaya Cooperative.  Comprised of the Batian, Ruiru 11, SL 28 and SL 34 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Certifications: Fair Trade Africa.  Kafe Coffee Roastery is a specialty roaster based in Zhubei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Citrusy, exceptionally sweet. Magrut lime, black cherry, watermelon candy, tarragon, sasparilla in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy acidity; very full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Resonant finish that leads with notes of magrut lime and watermelon candy with undertones of tarragon.
Notes: Produced by Denis Villatoro of Finca La Esperanza, entirely of the Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which whole fruit is fermented with limited oxygen before being dried. Intuition Coffee is a specialty roaster and cafe based in Peoria, Illinois. Visit

Coffee Origin: Pegasing, Takengon, Aceh Province, Sumatra, Indonesia
Blind Assessment: Deeply sweet, rich-toned. Snickerdoodle, cocoa nib, pomelo, tarragon, brown sugar in aroma and cup. Bright, balanced acidity; full, lightly creamy mouthfeel. Crisply cocoa-toned finish with notes of pomelo and brown sugar.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the Ateng, Bor Bor, Catimor and Timor varieties of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Utopian Coffee is a specialty roaster based in Fort Wayne, Indiana. Visit

Coffee Origin: Kabare, South Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo
Blind Assessment: Berry-toned, sweetly tart. Raspberry coulis, lemon verbena, baking chocolate, cedar, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Gentle, balanced acidity; full, very syrupy mouthfeel. Lemon verbena and baking chocolate carry the satisfying finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the Typica variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit) at the Katana Washing Station. Utopian Coffee is a specialty roaster based in Fort Wayne, Indiana. Visit

Coffee Origin: Nebilyer Valley, Western Highlands, Papua New Guinea
Blind Assessment: Bright, juicy, richly sweet. Pink grapefruit zest, lilac, cocoa nib, sugar cane, hazelnut in aroma and cup. Crisply sweet-tart acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Citrusy and floral-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by the Leahy family of Korgua Estate and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Utopian Coffee is a specialty roaster based in Fort Wayne, Indiana. Visit

Blind Assessment: Elegantly fruit-forward, citrusy-sweet. Pluot, finger lime, cocoa nib, rhododendron, bay leaf in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy acidity; very full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Finish leads with notes of pluot, finger lime and rhododendron.
Notes: Produced by the Sanchez Family of La Candelilla Estate, entirely of the Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious, high-quality coffee. Visit

Coffee Name: Kona Red Bourbon Anaerobic Washed Kona Rainforest
Coffee Origin: South Kona growing region, Big Island of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Delicately floral-toned, brightly citrusy. Wisteria, pink grapefruit, thyme, red plum, cocoa nib in aroma and cup. Juicy-sweet acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Very sweet, floral finish with undertones of cocoa nib and pink grapefruit.
Notes: Produced at the organic-certified Kona Rainforest Farm, entirely of the Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic washed method, with the addition of an organic yeast strain (developed in collaboration with Miguel Meza) to the fermentation. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit

Blind Assessment: Lush, richly aromatic, floral-toned. Star Jasmine, pink peppercorn, lychee, bergamot, fresh-cut cedar in aroma and cup. Delicately bright, vibrant acidity; full, syrupy smooth mouthfeel. Long, lingering, floral finish with undertones of bergamot and pink peppercorn.
Notes: Produced by Rodrigo Sanchez and Claudia Samboni, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (specifically, cold fermentation, in which the temperature-controlled tanks are set to 10-13 degrees Celsius). Hub Coffee Roasters is a specialty roaster focused on single-origin coffees, with several cafes in the Reno area. Visit

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Ethiopia Limu Baby Geisha Natural
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Deeply sweet, fruit-driven, lively. Dried apricot, dark chocolate, marshmallow, hazelnut, pink grapefruit zest in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with bright, juicy acidity; full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. The cleanly fruit-toned finish is supported by notes of hazelnut and dark chocolate.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Bargain Cafe is a specialty coffee roaster in Taitung, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Sweetly fruit-toned. Ripe blueberry, honey, cashew butter, lemon balm, baking chocolate in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with juicy-bright acidity; lightly satiny, smooth mouthfeel. The finish is centered around notes of honey and cashew.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of local heirloom varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Bargain Cafe is a specialty coffee roaster in Taitung, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Name: Panama Hacienda La Esmeralda Ethiopian Accessions
Blind Assessment: Elegant, complex, deeply sweet-savory. Bergamot, hop flowers, coriander, agave syrup, cocoa nib in aroma and cup. High-toned, bittersweet acidity; lush, silky mouthfeel. Finish leads with notes of bergamot and cocoa nib.
Notes: Produced at Hacienda La Esmeralda from plantings of wild and semi-wild varieties of Ethiopia Arabica in Costa Rica’s International Coffee Collection. These coffees were then blended and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit

Coffee Origin: Holualoa, Kona, Big Island of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet, caramelly. Dark caramel, guava, narcissus, oak, orange zest in aroma and cup. Bright, balanced acidity; lightly satiny mouthfeel. Orange zest and dark caramel are foregrounded in the finish.
Notes: Produced at Darnall Estate, entirely of the Kona Typica variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit

Blind Assessment: Brightly sweet-tart, balanced. Apricot, narcissus, tangerine zest, almond, cedar in aroma and cup. Juicy-bright acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Resonant finish that leads with notes of apricot and almond.
Notes: “Yellow” is a washed Ethiopia Chelbesa from the Yirgacheffe growing region, produced by smallholding farmers from trees of local heirloom varieties of Arabica. CMYK is a Billings, Montana-based coffee roaster that offers four primary coffees (like primary colors) that you can order “pure” or custom-blended to your own specifications. Visit

Coffee Origin: Sama, Ana Sora District, Oromia Region, Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Richly fruit-toned, elegantly restrained. Pineapple, cocoa nib, blackberry, lemon thyme, freesia in aroma and cup. Balanced, high-toned acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Pineapple and cocoa nib carry the long finish.
Notes: Produced by Israel Degefa entirely of the Wush Wush varierty of Arabica and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit) at the producer’s namesake washing station. Revel Coffee is a micro-roaster located in Billings, Montana. Its motto: “Quality is paramount – a difference you can revel in.” Visit

Coffee Origin: Holualoa, Kona, Big Island of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Richly aromatic, deep-toned. Wild honey, plumeria, white tea, peach, frankincense in aroma and cup. Bright, complex, juicy acidity; delicate, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Very sweet, multi-layered, resonant finish.
Notes: Produced by Franck Carisey, entirely of the SL34 variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried) with the addition of yeast during fermentation. Big Island Coffee is an award-winning coffee roaster operated with hands-on passion by Kelleigh Stewart and Brandon von Damitz. Visit

Blind Assessment: Brightly sweet-tart. Meyer lemon, date, Oreo cookie, almond nougat, freesia in aroma and cup. Juicy-bright acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Sweet-toned finish with notes of date and almond.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the SL28 and SL34 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Speedwell Coffee, based in Plymouth, Massachusetts, is a wholesale and retail specialty roaster particularly dedicated to offering attractive coffee subscription plans. For more information, visit

Blind Assessment: Balanced, sweetly bright. Apricot, cashew, cocoa nib, lemon verbena, cedar in aroma and cup. Gently bright, juicy acidity; crisp, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Satisfyingly cocoa-toned finish with undertones of lemon verbena.
Notes: Produced at Finca Las Palomas and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying).

Blind Assessment: Sweetly tart multi-layered. Pomegranate, salted caramel, cocoa nib, lime zest, cedar in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of pomegranate and cocoa nib.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying) at the Asman Gayo Mill.

Blind Assessment: Crisply chocolaty, sweetly tart. Tangerine, baking chocolate, fir, cashew, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; velvety-smooth mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of baking chocolate and fresh-cut fir.
Notes: An undisclosed bend of Arabica coffees. Reunion Coffee Roasters is a B-Corp-certified specialty coffee roastery with a cafe in downtown Toronto. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly tart, richly chocolaty. Baking chocolate, raspberry, frangipane, molasses, redwood in aroma and small cup. Plush, syrupy mouthfeel; crisp, chocolaty finish. In three parts milk, chocolate and raspberry notes carry the day, with undertones of redwood.
Notes: A blend of washed and natural-processed coffees from Colombia, Costa Rica and Honduras, roasted for espresso applications.

Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet, nut-toned. Almond, baking chocolate, blueberry, thyme, nutmeg in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with delicate acidity; full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Almond notes carry the finish, supported by thyme and nutmeg.
Notes: Produced by Iris Suyapa Chicas of Finca La Joya, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit).

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, earth-toned. Red apple, freesia, candycap mushroom, marjoram, baking chocolate in aroma and cup. Brisk acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Finish centers around notes of candy cap mushroom and baking chocolate.
Notes: A blend of coffees, both washed and natural-processed, from Colombia, Sumatra, Costa Rica and Honduras.

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Boldly sweet, gently roasty. Baking chocolate, almond, pomegranate, fir, molasses in aroma and small cup. Lightly satiny mouthfeel; gently crisp, nutty finish. In cappuccino-scaled milk, both chocolate and nut tones bloom.
Notes: Sales support the Grounds for Health non-profit. Reunion Coffee Roasters is a B-Corp-certified specialty coffee roastery with a cafe in downtown Toronto. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Chocolaty, richly nut-toned. Dark chocolate, almond butter, Meyer lemon zest, pink peppercorn, fir in aroma and small cup. Velvety-smooth mouthfeel; chocolaty, nut-driven finish. In cappuccino-scaled milk, notes of dark chocolate and pink peppercorn commingle with fir.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers and decaffeinated in Colombia using ethyl acetate, a solvent derived from sugar cane. Side By Each Brewing Co. is a community gathering place to enjoy coffee, beer, food and music. The company closed permanently in December 2024.

Blind Assessment: Deep-toned, roast-rounded. Dark chocolate, gently scorched oak, date, hazelnut, musk in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Finish centers around notes of pleasingly smoky dark chocolate and hazelnut.
Notes: An blend of certified USDA Organic and Fair Trade coffees. Reunion Coffee Roasters is a B-Corp-certified specialty coffee roastery with a cafe in downtown Toronto. Visit

Blind Assessment: Sweetly roast-toned, chocolaty. Cocoa powder, hazelnut, gardenia, date, fir in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; creamy, viscous mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned and floral finish.
Notes: A blend of two washed coffees, one from Colombia and one from Costa Rica.

Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Multi-layered, rich-toned. Bing cherry, coconut, candied violet, frankincense, cocoa nib in aroma and cup. Balanced, high-toned acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Crisp, sweetly tart finish that goes on and on.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 10 coffee on

Coffee Name: Panama Mokkita Natural Mama Cata Estate
Blind Assessment: Richly floral, fruit-saturated. Wild strawberry, lavender fields, cedar, honey, black sage in aroma and cup. Sparkling, floral acidity; vivacious, silly mouthfeel. Floral and fruit notes take gracious turns in the long, inviting finish.
Notes: Produced by the Garrido family of Mama Cata Farm, entirely of the rare Mokkita variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit

Coffee Origin: Ka‘ū growing region, “Big Island” of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Rich-toned, complex, fruit-driven. Dried apricot, lychee, amber, hop flowers, tangerine in aroma and cup. Crisp, apple-like acidity; plush, viscous mouth feel. Finish focused around notes of dried apricot and amber with compelling floral undertones.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 18 coffee on

Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Balanced, juicy, delicately sweet-tart. Nectarine, almond, cocoa nib, star jasmine, oak forest in aroma and cup. Sparkling acidity; crisp, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Cohesive, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Produced at Heavenly Hawaiian Farm, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Founded by Dave and Trudy Bateman in 1994, Heavenly Hawaiian is a coffee farm and roastery in Kona that offers daily farm tours as well as retail sales. Visit

Coffee Name: JN Farms Double Anaerobic Red Bourbon
Coffee Origin: Ka‘ū growing region, Big Island of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Deeply floral-toned, richly fruity. Narcissus, pineapple, cocoa nib, marjoram, wild honey in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthfeel. Floral-driven finish supported by cocoa nib and wild honey.
Notes: Produced by Leo Norberte of JN Farms, entirely of the Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method (fermented in an oxygen-free environment, then dried in the whole fruit). Founded by roaster Heather Brisson-Lutz in 2018, Origin Coffee Roasters highlights the origin of each carefully selected coffee with a roast profile that highlights the specific characteristics of the green. Visit

Coffee Origin: Ka‘ū growing district, "Big Island" of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Deeply sweet, richly savory. Chocolate fudge, almond butter, date, macadamia nut, cedar in aroma and cup. Gentle, vibrant, balanced acidity; very full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Chocolaty finish with undertones of almond and macadamia nut.
Notes: This 100% Ka’u coffee was developed by Lorie Obra of Rusty’s, one of Ka‘ū’s best-known and most celebrated farms. Produced from trees of the Typica variety of Arabica and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Visit

Coffee Origin: Kona growing region, Big Island of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Sweet-toned, chocolaty and rich. Dark chocolate, strawberry guava, almond brittle, cedar, freesia in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with bright, engaging acidity; full, creamy mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of dark chocolate, almond and freesia.
Notes: Produced by Kona Farm Direct, entirely of the Kona Typica variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Kraig and Leslie Lee have been growing and harvesting traditional Kona Coffee for over 25 years. In 2017, they introduced several distinguished new tree varieties to their 4.7-acre farm. Visit

Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Sweet-toned, crisply chocolaty. Baking chocolate, hazelnut, red apple, cedar, Meyer lemon zest in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; lightly satiny, buoyant mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of baking chocolate and hazelnut.
Notes: Produced at Monarch Farm, entirely of the Kona Typica variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). The Hapa is a blend of three roast levels: light, medium and dark. Monarch Coffee is an award-winning coffee farm and specialty roaster of 100% estate-grown Kona coffee on the Big Island of Hawai’i. Visit

Coffee Origin: North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Citrusy, deeply floral. Pink grapefruit, lilac, baking chocolate, bay leaf, brown sugar in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Sweetly herbaceous finish with undertones of crisp chocolate notes.
Notes: Produced at Hala Tree Farm entirely of the SL28 variety of Arabica and processed by the honey method, in which some of the fruit flesh is left on the beans during the drying process. Hala Tree Coffee is a family-owned coffee farm in the heart of the Kona coffee belt, overlooking historic Kealakekua Bay. The 100% Kona Coffee produced on this USDA organic-certified property is processed and roasted on site to ensure quality. For more information, visit

Coffee Origin: Ka‘ū growing region, “Big Island” of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-savory, deep-toned. Raspberry compote, rhododendron, agave syrup, lemon verbena, sweet cream in aroma and cup. Even-keeled acidity; creamy-smooth mouthfeel. Finish centers around notes of raspberry and rhododendron.
Notes: Produced by Delvin and Nette Navarro of Navarro Coffee Farm, from trees of the Pacamara and Catuai varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method

Coffee Name: Ecuador Finca Cruz Loma Washed Anaerobic
Coffee Origin: San José de Minas, Pichincha Province, Ecuador
Blind Assessment: Nuanced, enigmatic. Clove, dark chocolate, macerated kiwi, roasted hazelnut, tarragon in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Spice-toned finish with chocolate and kiwi accents.
Notes: Produced by husband and wife Galo Morales and Maria Alexandra Rivera and their family at Finca Cruz Loma, entirely of the Sidra variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic washed method, in which the fermentation step occurs in a hermetically sealed vessel before the beans are washed and dried. Visit

Coffee Origin: Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Sweetly nutty, crisply chocolaty. Cashew butter, baking chocolate, caramel, fresh-cut fir, orange zest in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Richly nut-toned finish supported by distinct baking chocolate notes.
Notes: Produced by Mike Takizawa of Kona Hills Farm, entirely of the Kona Typica variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Kona Hills Coffee is a five-acre farm and roastery owned and operated by Kona native Mike Takizawa. Visit

Blind Assessment: Sweetly nutty and fruit-toned. Cashew, golden raisin, fir, orange zest, cane sugar in aroma and cup. Brisk acidity; velvety mouthfeel. Nut-driven finish with undertones of golden raisin and orange zest.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Honduras and Maui, one washed and one natural-processed. Hanalei Coffee Roasters is a small-batch coffee roaster that offers both Hawaiian-grown  coffees and coffees from other origins. Visit

Blind Assessment: Crisply chocolaty, sweetly nut-toned. Almond, cocoa powder, fresh-cut fir, salted caramel, pear in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; lightly satiny mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned finish with a sweet almond throughline.
Notes: A blend of three Hawaiian coffees: a Typica from Ka‘ū on the Big Island, a Red Catuai from Maui, and a Typica from O’ahu, all washed-process. Founded by David Gridley in 1993, Maui ‘Oma has both a wholesale and a retail operation. It specializes in Hawaiian coffees but also roasts coffees from other origins.
