Barrington Coffee is an artisan roaster dedicated to elite coffees, fresh delivery, and roasting that foregrounds the coffee and not the roast. Visit

Blind Assessment: Sweetly spice-toned, uniquely composed. Szechuan peppercorn, lemon balm, dark chocolate, lavender, date in aroma and cup. Winy acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthful. Chocolaty, spice-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by Edwin Noreña of Finca Campo Hermoso, entirely of the Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the carbonic maceration method, as follows: The whole fruit is co-fermented with aji chili must in oxygen-free containers for 96 hours. The fruit is then semi-washed (some of the fruit flesh is left on the bean), then returned to the carbonic fermentation tanks and re-infused with fresh aji chili must for an additional 48 hours. After the secondary carbonic fermentation, the coffee is dried on raised beds for 22 days and then set in a relative humidity-controlled warehouse for a final eight days of repose. Barrington Coffee is an artisan roaster dedicated to elite coffees, fresh delivery, and roasting that foregrounds the coffee and not the roast. Visit

Blind Assessment: Delicately fruit-toned, crisply chocolaty. Raspberry, baking chocolate, pralines, cedar, orange zest in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. The finish is chocolaty and berry-toned.
Notes: Produced by Maeggi Rodriguez and sons Jorge and Juan Pablo from trees of the Caturra, Mondo Novo and Catuai varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Nostalgia Coffee Roasters was founded by Taylor Fields in 2018 as a mobile café; it has since added specialty roasting, an online store, a café, and a national wholesale program featuring select fine coffees. Visit

Blind Assessment: A classic Yirgacheffe cup, balanced and bright, with notes of stone fruit, cocoa nib, and citrus throughout — harmonious, integrated, and lyrically juicy.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of heirloom varieties of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed at the Chelbessa Washing Station by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Coffee Origin: Chelchele, Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: High-toned, fruit-forward. Dried mango, cocoa nib, lemongrass, sandalwood, magnolia in aroma and cup. Balanced, sweetly tart structure with juicy acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The harmonious finish leads with magnolia and mango notes with sandalwood undertones.
Notes: Produced by the METAD farm and mill in southern Ethiopia and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Sweetly tart, very fruity. Watermelon candy, dried lychee, cocoa nib, oak, Meyer lemon zest in aroma and cup. Lively, bright acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Very long, flavor-laden, rich-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of CoopeTarrazú, from trees of the Caturra and Catuai varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Coffee Name: Colombia Huila Espiritu Blanc Geisha Semi-Washed Anaerobic
Blind Assessment: Floral-toned, sweetly tart. Strawberry, guava, dark chocolate, star jasmine zest, honey, lemon thyme in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with juicy-bright acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Delicately floral finish with undertones of deep chocolate.
Notes: Produced by Wilder Lazo of Finca Belle Alejandria, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic semi-washed method, in which the coffee fruit, with some of the pulp left on the bean, is fermented in a hermetically sealed environment before drying. Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Richly fruit-toned. Blackberry jam, dark chocolate, marjoram, freesia, fresh-cut oak in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with fruity acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of blackberry and marjoram.
Notes: Produced by the 847 smallholding farmers surrounding the Umoco Washing Station, entirely of the Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Blind Assessment: Spice-toned, balanced. Nutmeg, lemon balm, jasmine, fig, fir in aroma and cup. Brisk acidity; crisply velvety mouthfeel. Wood-framed, lemony finish with undertones of fig.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers of the Boa Bedegelo Cooperative, from heirloom varieties of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Certifications: USDA Organic; Fair Trade Federation. Dean's Beans is a small batch wholesale roaster devoted to organic and sustainable principles and small-holder support. Visit

Blind Assessment: Intensely aromatic, delicately fruit-forward. Milk chocolate, orange zest, cedar, candied apple, hint of narcissus in aroma and cup. Gently brisk acidy; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Fruit-toned chocolate in the crisp finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of the Othaya Cooperative, entirely of the SL28 variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Certifications: Fair Trade Africa. Fulcrum Coffee Roasters is a Seattled-based wholesale coffee roaster and retailer with two cafes, one in Seattle and one in Mountlake Terrace. Visit

Coffee Origin: Aleta Wendo, Sidamo growing region, south-central Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Citrusy, floral-toned. Mandarin orange, tea rose, blackberry, cashew, fir in aroma and cup. Gentle, mild acidity; silky-smooth mouthfeel. Gently drying finish with notes of orange and fir.
Notes: Produced by smallhodling farmers, from heirloom varieties of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Certifications: USDA Organic; FLOCERT. Based in southern Oregon, Noble Coffee Roasting is a wholesale and retail roasting company focused on quality, social responsibility and environmental awareness. Visit

Blind Assessment: Gently floral, fruity. Magnolia, blueberry, hazelnut, baking chocolate, Graham cracker in aroma and cup. Winy acidity; crisply satiny mouthfeel. The quiet finish leads with notes of magnolia and hazelnut.
Notes: Produced by Homer Alarcon Gayoso, entirely of the Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Certifications: Fair Trade International (FLOCERT). The company name Amavida combines the Spanish words for love and life, reflecting Amavida’s multifaceted commitment to fairness and fine coffee. For more information, visit

Coffee Origin: Northern Province, Gakenke District, Ruli, Rwanda
Blind Assessment: Lively, fruit- and spice-toned. Persimmon, black cherry, cinnamon, violet, cedar in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet-tart structure with lightly satiny mouthfeel. Finish reminiscent of baking spices with black cherry undertones.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers of the Dukundekawa Women's Cooperative, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Certifications: Fair Trade USA; Rainforest Alliance Organic. Founded in 2019, Three Keys is a craft coffee roastery in Houston, Texas. The company name is inspired by the valves of the trumpet, which has been the instrument of choice for some of the most influential jazz musicians and composers. Three Keys says its coffees “speak a language that’s sophisticated yet accessible to everyone who’s willing to slow down and share a cup.” Visit

Blind Assessment: Sweetly nutty. Almond, green grape, star anise, caramel, buttered toast in aroma and cup. Gentle, balanced acidity; very syrupy mouthfeel. Green grape and caramel notes are front and venter in the crisp finish.
Notes: Produced by Porfirio Velasquez, from trees of the Bourbon, Caturra and Sarchimor varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Certifications: FLOCERT. Wonderstate Coffee, formerly Kickapoo Coffee, is an award-winning roaster based in rural Wisconsin known for its commitment to guaranteeing higher pay for farmers and operating the country’s first 100% solar-powered roastery. Visit

Blind Assessment: Delicately sweet, berry-toned. Strawberry, honey roasted nuts, Ruby Port, balsa in aroma and cup. Sweetly brisk acidity; velvety mouthfee. Long, crisp finish with lingering berry and nut tones.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from heirloom varieties of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Certifications: USDA Organic; Fair Trade USA. Red Rock Roasters was founded in Albuquerque, New Mexico in 1993 in a family barn and remains family-owned and focused on quality and freshness. Visit

Coffee Origin: Aceh Province, Gayo Highlands, Sumatra, Indonesia
Blind Assessment: Deep-toned, straightforward and savory-leaning. Fresh humus, cocoa powder, gardenia extract, pecan, fir in aroma and cup. Savory, low-toned acidity; crisply satiny mouthfeel. Gently drying finish centered around notes of fresh humus, pecan and fir.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of the Koperasi Ketiara Cooperative, a longtime origin partner of Colectivo. Coffees like this one from the northern part of the Indonesian island of Sumatra are valued for their complex earth and fruit notes that appear to result largely from unorthodox fruit removal and drying practices called “wet-hulling.” Certifications: USDA Organic; Fair Trade International. Colectivo Coffee, founded in 1993, is a Milwaukee-based specialty roaster with 20 cafes in Milwaukee, Madison, and Chicago. Visit

Blind Assessment: Muted, crisply chocolaty. Baking chocolate, graphite, cashew, lily, brown sugar in aroma and cup. Sharp acidity; light-bodied mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of graphite and brown sugar.
Notes: Purchased at an Oakland, California Whole Foods Market. Certifications: Fair Trade USA; Non-GMO. Processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Allegro Coffee, a subsidiary of Whole Foods Market, offers one of the country’s largest selections of single-origin coffees. Visit www.allegrocoffee.com or call 800-227-1107 for more information.

Coffee Name: Organic Fair Trade Shade Grown Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Staunchly dark roasted, somewhat smoky. Carob, walnut, scorched fir, lily, stale raisin in aroma and cup. Harsh acidity; thin mouthfeel. Ashy finish with only slight sweetness.
Notes: Purchased at a Trader Joe’s market in Alameda, California. Processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Certified USDA Organic and Fair Trade USA. Trader Joe’s is a discount gourmet and natural foods supermarket chain with 457 stores in more than 20 states. Visit

Blind Assessment: Simple, sweet, lean. Salted caramel, wheat toast, green bean, vanilla extract, plywood in aroma and cup. Flat acidity; rough mouthfeel. Sweet-savory finish with notes of salted caramel and green bean.
Notes: Purchased at a Whole Foods Market in Oakland, California. Certifications: Fair Trade USA; Non-GMO. Whole Foods Market is a retail grocer currently owned by Amazon with more than 500 stores in North America and the UK. Visit

Blind Assessment: Plushly nut-toned, richly aromatic. Hazelnut butter, date, maple syrup, pink grapefruit zest, hint of bay leaf in aroma and cup. Balanced, even-keeled acidity; crisp, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Hazelnut notes foreground the gentle finish.
Notes: Produced by Sergio and Walter Romero of La Lesquiñada Farm, entirely of the Parainema variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features selections from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit

Coffee Name: Costa Rica San Ramon Yeast Washed
Blind Assessment: Delicately sweet, floral-toned. Narcissus, almond, bergamot, cherry, cedar in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Floral, nut-toned finish.
Notes: Produced at Finca San Ramon, from trees of the Caturra and Catuai varieties of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying) with the addition of yeasts to the fermentation process. Kafe Coffee Roastery is a specialty roaster based in Zhubei, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Name: DR Congo Muungnano Natural Single-Origin Espresso
Coffee Origin: South Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Very fruit-sweet, spice-toned. Mulberry, clove, cocoa powder, almond, daffodil in aroma and small cup. Lightly satiny mouthfeel; fruity, spice-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers of the Muungano Cooperative, entirely of the Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features selections from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Crisply chocolaty, fruit-toned. Baking chocolate, raspberry, Graham cracker, orange zest, fir in aroma and small cup. Velvety-smooth mouthfeel; chocolaty finish with undertones of orange zest. In three parts milk, baking chocolate presides, supported by notes of Graham cracker and fir.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Costa Rica, Indonesia and Ethiopia, roasted for espresso applications. Kafe Coffee Roastery is a specialty roaster based in Zhubei, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Origin: Ka‘ū and Kona growing regions, Big Island of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Balanced, chocolaty, and richly fruit-forward. Dried pineapple, dark chocolate, hazelnut brittle, magnolia, tangerine zest in aroma and small cup. Creamy mouthfeel; crisply chocolaty finish with tropical fruit undertones. In three parts milk, dark chocolate predominates, supported by tangerine zest and pineapple notes.
Notes: A blend of coffees, both natural-processed and washed, from multiple farms in Ka‘ū and Kona, including Typica, Bourbon, Red Catuai, K7 and Maragogype varieties of Arabica. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit

Coffee Origin: Carmo de Mata, Campo das Vertentes, Minas Gerais, Brazil
Blind Assessment: Fruity, sweetly tart. Fruit Loops, pomegranate juice, cashew, lemon verbena, cedar in aroma and cup. Brisk acidity; velvety-smooth mouthfeel. Quietly fruit-forward, crisply nutty finish.
Notes: Produced by Monica Borges de Sousa of Fazenda Vila Boa, entirely of the Yellow Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which the whole fruit is fermented in an oxygen-free environment before drying. Rainforest Alliance-certified. Virginia-based specialty roaster Pinup Coffee Co. focuses on affordable, accessible and carefully roasted coffees from all over the world. Visit

Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-savory. Toffee, pomegranate, cedar, hazelnut, candied violet in aroma and cup. Richly bittersweet structure with brisk acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The crisp finish consolidates to notes of pomegranate and hazelnut.
Notes: A blend of three coffees: a washed Ethiopia, a washed Kenya and a natural-processed Brazil. CoffeeBox Coffee founders Godfrey and Coco focus on small-batch coffee roasting with the goal of making the joy of premium coffee accessible to everyone. Visit

Blind Assessment: Floral-driven, crisply bright. Lilac, apricot, cocoa nib, tangerine zest, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with high-toned acidity; lightly satiny mouthfeel. The finish leads with notes of lilac and apricot with undertones of cocoa nib.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Colombia and Ethiopia, both processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). CoffeeBox Coffee founders Godfrey and Coco focus on small-batch coffee roasting with the goal of making the joy of premium coffee accessible to everyone. Visit

Blind Assessment: Complex, multi-layered. Pomegranate, red wine barrel, rhododendron, kefir, kumquat in aroma and cup. Brisk acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Finish leads with notes of wine barrel and kefir.
Notes: Produced by Denise Bustamonte, entirely of the Robusta species, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which the whole fruit is fermented in tanks with limited oxygen before drying, also in the whole fruit. In this case, lactic acid was added to the fermentation step. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit

Blind Assessment: Sweetly roast-rounded. Cocoa powder, gently scorched oak, gardenia, raisin, vanilla bean in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; full, creamy mouthfeel. Gently drying finish with notes of cocoa powder and scorched oak.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Brazil, Ethiopia and Colombia. Virginia-based specialty roaster Pinup Coffee Co. focuses on affordable, accessible and carefully roasted coffees from all over the world. Visit

Blind Assessment: Brewed in a Toddy Small-Batch Artisan Brewer and evaluated chilled. Rich-toned, chocolaty. Dark chocolate syrup, dried plum, lily, almond brittle, gently scorched cedar in aroma and cup. Crisp, viscous mouthfeel; crisply chocolaty finish with undertones of smoky cedar. With milk, chocolate-saturated, complicated by scorched cedar and fried plum notes.
Notes: A whole-bean coffee sourced and roasted for cold brewing at home. For this review brewed at the

Blind Assessment: Crisp, chocolaty, sweetly nut-toned. Baking chocolate, hazelnut, rhododendron, date, gently scorched fir in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; full, creamy mouthfeel. Gently drying, nut-toned, wood-framed finish.
Notes: A blend of three coffees: a washed Colombia, a washed Ethiopia and a natural-processed Brazil. CoffeeBox Coffee founders Godfrey and Coco focus on small-batch coffee roasting with the goal of making the joy of premium coffee accessible to everyone. Visit

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-savory, deep-toned. Ripe tomato, cocoa nib, black currant, bay leaf, pink grapefruit zest in aroma and cup. High-toned, juicy acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Resonant finish that carries over all the aromas and flavors of the cup.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 12 coffee on

Coffee Origin: El Aguacatal, Hoja Blanca, Cuilco, Huehuetenango, Guatemala
Blind Assessment: Complexly fruity, cocoa-toned. Boysenberry, pomelo, cocoa nib, cedar, frankincense in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart acidity; full, creamy mouthfeel. Deeply fruity finish with cocoa nib undertones.
Notes: Produced by Petronilo Martinez and his son Petronilo Jesus, entirely of the Maragoype variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Big Shoulders Coffee is a Chicago artisan roaster that emphasizes a fresh-roasted, no-nonsense approach to fine coffee. Visit

Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: High-toned, fruit-driven. Mulberry, cocoa nib, tangerine zest, pink peppercorn, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with juicy-bright acidity; viscous, velvety mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of mulberry and tangerine zest with undertones of pink peppercorn.
Notes: Guji is nestled next to the better-known Yirgacheffe and Sidamo growing regions; it shares their devotion to the distinctive, largely indigenous varieties of Arabica long grown in these regions. This is a “natural” or dry-processed version (dried in the whole fruit). Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit

Coffee Name: Mario’s Classic Espresso Single-Origin El Salvador
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Richly sweet, spice-toned. Dark caramel, clove, black cherry, magnolia, lemon verbena in aroma and small cup. Crisp, satiny mouthfeel; caramel-toned finish with magnolia undertones. In cappuccino format, caramel and clove take center stage with support from lemon verbena.
Notes: Produced by Mario Valiente of Calera Specialty Coffee Farm, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). RamsHead Coffee Roasters is a family-owned company founded by Bozeman, Montana natives Caleb and Laura Walker that specializes in direct trade microlot coffees. For more information, visit

Blind Assessment: Delicately fruit-toned. Sweetly herbaceous. Lychee, star anise, lemon balm, oak, freesia in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to lychee and anise.
Notes: Produced by

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe Worka Nenke Abraham Mengiste
Blind Assessment: Delicate, richly complex. Narcissus, raspberry, cocoa nib, cedar, myrrh in aroma and cup. Richly sweet structure with bright, balanced acidity; elegant, silky mouthfeel. Floral finish with a cocoa throughline.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers near the

Blind Assessment: Fruit-driven, richly cocoa-toned. Nectarine, dark chocolate, violet, pink grapefruit zest, graphite in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart acidity; very full, viscous mouthfeel. Resonant, long, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Founded in 1990, Roadmap CoffeeWorks, formerly Lexington Coffee Roasters, is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Lexington, Virginia. Roadmap CoffeeWorks focuses on producing fresh, distinctive and sustainable coffees. Visit

Blind Assessment: Bright sweet, citrus-toned. Bergamot, bay leaf, cocoa nib, narcissus, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Juicy, sparkling acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Long, resonant, flavor-laden finish.
Notes: Produced from trees of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Lee Dong Coffee is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taichung, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Bench Maji Gesha Winey Natural G1
Blind Assessment: Complexly fruit-toned, sweetly fermenty. Star jasmine, strawberry, cocoa nib, bay leaf, wine barrel in aroma and cup. Juicy-bright acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The resonant finish centers around notes of cocoa-toned strawberry and a hint of wine barrel.
Notes: Produced in the Bench-Maji Zone of southern Ethiopia, entirely of the Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Lee Dong Coffee is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taichung, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Name: Costa Rica Las Lajas Finca Mirella
Coffee Origin: Sabanilla de Alajuela, Central Valley, Costa Rica
Blind Assessment: Delicately fruity, balanced. Passion fruit, dark chocolate, pralines, marjoram, cedar in aroma and cup. Gently sweet-tart acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Finish centers around notes of passion fruit and marjoram.
Notes: Produced by Francisca and Oscar Chacon of Finca Las Lajas, from trees of the Caturra and Catuai varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Founded in 1990, Roadmap CoffeeWorks, formerly Lexington Coffee Roasters, is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Lexington, Virginia. Roadmap CoffeeWorks focuses on producing fresh, distinctive and sustainable coffees. Visit

Blind Assessment: Richly chocolaty, balanced. Dark chocolate, peach, almond, cedar, lemon-thyme in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Chocolaty, nut-toned finish with cedar and herb notes.
Notes: Produced by Arturo Aguirre of El Injerto Farm, from trees of the Catuai variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed before beans are dried). Coffeeland is a specialty coffee roastery with two locations, one in Chia-Yi, Taiwan, and one in Ontario, California. Visit

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Washed G1 Twakok Lot
Blind Assessment: Floral-toned, crisply sweet. Freesia, apricot, baking chocolate, tangerine zest, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with brisk acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The finish leads with notes of freesia and apricot with undertones of baking chocolate.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmer, from heirloom varieties of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Lee Dong Coffee is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taichung, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Origin: Bombe mountains, Sidamo Region, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Gently tart, citrus-toned. Ripe orange, lemon balm, cocoa powder, date, fir in aroma and cup. Brisk acidity; full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Gently drying finish consolidates to notes of orange zest, fir and cocoa powder.
Notes: Coffees from the Sidama region like this one are produced from distinctive, largely indigenous Ethiopian landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Coffeeland is a specialty coffee roastery with two locations, one in Chia-Yi, Taiwan, and one in Ontario, California. Visit

Blind Assessment: Deep-toned, richly sweet. Dark chocolate, salted caramel, dried persimmon, pistachio, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with gentle acidity; full, syrupy smooth mouthfeel. Chocolaty finish supported by salted caramel and pistachio.
Notes: Produced by Alejandro Solís of Finca Huixoc entirely of the Pacamara variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). El Gran Cafe is a coffee shop located in the heart of Antigua, Guatemala whose mission is to roast and serve organic-certified coffees produced at its own Finca La Esperanza just outside of town. Featured in El Gran Cafe’s lineup are also coffees from friends and neighbors in the region, along with award-winning and exceptional coffees from other regions of Guatemala. Visit

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-savory, cocoa-toned. Cocoa powder, lily, black cherry, fresh-cut oak, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Balanced structure with brisk acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to cocoa-toned black cherry and oak.
Notes: Produced by Alejandro Solís of Finca Huixoc entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). El Gran Cafe is a coffee shop located in the heart of Antigua, Guatemala whose mission is to roast and serve organic-certified coffees produced at its own Finca La Esperanza just outside of town. Featured in El Gran Cafe’s lineup are also coffees from friends and neighbors in the region, along with award-winning and exceptional coffees from other regions of Guatemala. Visit

Blind Assessment: Gently sweet-tart, crisply herbaceous. Baking chocolate, green grape, lemon verbena, fresh-cut oak, sugarcane in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The sweetly herbaceous finish centers around notes of lemon verbena and sugarcane supported by fresh-cut oak.
Notes: Produced by Finca Santa Elisa entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried).

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Deep-toned, richly chocolaty. Baking chocolate, pomegranate, marjoram, grapefruit zest, molasses in aroma and small cup. Crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel; balanced, chocolaty and citrus-toned finish. In cappuccino-scaled milk, baking chocolate and pomegranate notes harmonize nicely.
Notes: Produced by Don Alejandro López at Volcán de Agua and processed at Finca La Esperanza by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried).

Blind Assessment: Crisp, delicately sweet. Dried pear, caramel, pecan, orange zest, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with gentle acidity; full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. The gently crisp finish leads with caramel and notes.
Notes: Produced by Finca Rosario de Fátima entirely of the Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried).

Blind Assessment: Sweetly citrusy, bright. Orange zest, baking chocolate, agave syrup, freesia, cashew in aroma and cup. Tart-leaning structure with brisk acidity; velvety mouthfeel. The gently drying finish consolidates to notes of baking chocolate and freesia.
Notes: Produced by Andres Fahsen of Finca Retana entirely of the Maracaturra variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried).

Blind Assessment: Sweet-toned, crisply chocolaty. Baking chocolate, raisin, carnation, cashew, fir in aroma and cup. Sweet-savory structure with brisk acidity; lightly silky mouthfeel. Gently drying, wood-framed finish with hints of carnation and cashew.
Notes: Produced by Finca San José Ocaña entirely of Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried).

Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet, delicately fruity. Blueberry, baking chocolate, hazelnut orange zest, oak in aroma and cup. Brisk acidity; satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Gently drying finish centered around notes of baking chocolate and oak.
Notes: A blend of two coffees, an Ethiopia natural and a wash-processed Colombia. Founded in 2007 and named after the white rhino, which is both rare and social, White Rhino Coffee is based in Dallas, Texas and currently has nine coffee shops in addition to its roastery. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly nut-toned, caramelly. Dark caramel, almond, pomegranate, cedar, thyme in aroma and small cup. Crisply satiny mouthfeel; caramel- and nut-toned finish. In three parts milk, sweetness is amplified, juxtaposed with a tart pomegranate note.
Notes: A blend of two coffees, a natural-processed Brazil and a washed Peru, roasted for espresso applications. Founded in 2007 and named after the white rhino, which is both rare and social, White Rhino Coffee is based in Dallas, Texas and currently has nine coffee shops in addition to its roastery. Visit

Blind Assessment: Bright, richly sweet-tart. Cocoa nib, nectarine, narcissus, almond, brown sugar in aroma and cup. High-toned, juicy acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. The finish centers around notes of cocoa nib and nectarine.
Notes: Produced by Josué Morales of Finca El Potrero from trees of the Sarchimor and Anacafé 14 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). Certified USDA Organic.

Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-savory. Toffee, tamarind, cedar, almond brittle, candied violet in aroma and cup. Complex, bittersweet structure with juicy acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Sweetly tart finish consolidates to notes of tamarind and almond brittle.
Notes: Produced at Beneficio La Esperanza from trees of the Bourbon, Caturra and Caturai varieties of Arabica and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). Proyecto Aurora is a special project of the employees of Beneficio La Esperanza on the parcels they own in Ciudad Vieja and Alotenango. Coffee is picked only on Sunday, as this is the only day of the week they are not occupied picking coffee on other parcels. El Gran Cafe is a coffee shop located in the heart of Antigua, Guatemala whose mission is to roast and serve organic-certified coffees produced at its own Finca La Esperanza just outside of town. Featured in El Gran Cafe’s lineup are also coffees from friends and neighbors in the region, along with award-winning and exceptional coffees from other regions of Guatemala. Visit

Coffee Origin: San Cristobal Verapaz, Alta Verapaz, Guatemala
Blind Assessment: Richly floral and aromatic. Narcissus, black currant, cocoa nib, thyme, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with bright, juicy acidity; full, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The finish leads with notes of narcissus and black currant with undertones of cocoa nib.
Notes: Produced by Luis Wicho Valdes of Finca Santa Isabel exclusively from trees of the Caturra variety of Arabica and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). El Gran Cafe is a coffee shop located in the heart of Antigua, Guatemala whose mission is to roast and serve organic-certified coffees produced at its own Finca La Esperanza just outside of town. Featured in El Gran Cafe’s lineup are also coffees from friends and neighbors in the region, along with award-winning and exceptional coffees from other regions of Guatemala. Visit

Coffee Origin: San Lucas Tolimán, Lake Atitlán, Guatemala
Blind Assessment: Delicate, sweetly nut-toned. Cashew butter, ginger blossom, fresh-cut fir, caramel, hint of red grape in aroma and small cup. Gentle, round acidity; velvety-smooth mouthfeel. The richly nut-framed finish is supported by notes of ginger blossom and caramel.
Notes: Produced by Andres Fahsen of Finca Patzibar entirely of the Catuai variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). Certified USDA Organic.

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, chocolaty. Baking chocolate, hazelnut, golden raisin, gardenia, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with round acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Chocolaty finish with undertones of hazelnut and cedar.
Notes: Produced by Josué Morales of Finca La Esperanza entirely of the Villa Sarchi variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). Certified USDA Organic.

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-savory. Butterscotch, thyme, red apple, hop flowers, cedar in aroma and cup. Balanced acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Resonant finish consolidates to notes of red apple and butterscotch with cedar undertones.
Notes: Produced by Higinio Gómez of Beneficio La Esperanza, from trees of the Yellow and Red Pacamara varieties of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). Featured in El Gran Cafe’s lineup are also coffees from friends and neighbors in the region, along with award-winning and exceptional coffees from other regions of Guatemala. Visit

Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-tart, pleasingly nutty. Red apple, almond brittle, freesia, lime zest, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with brisk acidity; delicate, satiny mouthfeel. Quiet, gently nut-toned finish.
Notes: Produced at Beneficio La Esperanza from trees of the Bourbon, Caturra and Catuaí varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). Blind Assessment: Crisply nut-toned. Pecan, raisin, sage, brown sugar, fir in aroma and cup. Bittersweet structure with gentle acidity. Chewy, round mouthfeel. Pecan notes prevail in a gently drying finish.
Notes: Produced at Beneficio La Esperanza from trees of the Bourbon, Caturra and Caturai varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). Featured in El Gran Cafe’s lineup are also coffees from friends and neighbors in the region, along with award-winning and exceptional coffees from other regions of Guatemala. Visit

Blind Assessment: Sweetly nut-toned. Roasted hazelnut, cedar, cocoa powder, date, daisy in aroma and cup. Bittersweet structure with gentle acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. The gently drying finish consolidates to cocoa-toned cedar.
Notes: Produced at Beneficio La Esperanza at Finca San Carlos from trees of the Bourbon and Catuai varieties of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried).

Blind Assessment: Crisp, quietly sweet. Brazil nut, carob, dried orange zest, carnation, muted raisin in aroma and cup. Savory structure with tart acidity; dry, velvety mouthfeel. Quiet nut-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by Higinio Gómez of Beneficio La Esperanza, entirely of the Yellow Caturra variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). El Gran Cafe is a coffee shop located in the heart of Antigua, Guatemala whose mission is to roast and serve organic-certified coffees produced at its own Finca La Esperanza just outside of town. Featured in El Gran Cafe’s lineup are also coffees from friends and neighbors in the region, along with award-winning and exceptional coffees from other regions of Guatemala. Visit

Blind Assessment: Delicately fruity, richly floral-toned. Froot Loops cereal, crimson lily, cocoa nib, tangerine zest, bay leaf in aroma and cup. Delicate juicy acidity; silky-smooth mouthfeel. Lily and cocoa nib support a crisply fruity finish.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez, entirely of the Sidra variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, with the fermentation of the whole fruit preceded by sterilization with ozone gas and ultraviolet light and with yeasts added to the fermentation. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Chocolaty, fruity, nutty. Dark chocolate, hazelnut butter, pomegranate, marjoram, cedar in aroma and small cup. Crisply satiny mouthfeel; richly chocolaty, nut-toned finish. In three parts milk, a trifecta of dark chocolate, hazelnut and pomegranate resonate in balanced harmony.
Notes: A blend of coffees from undisclosed South and Central America and Africa origins. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Blind Assessment: Sweetly chocolaty and nut-toned. Baking chocolate, almond brittle, gardenia, cherry soda, cedar in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; full, creamy mouthfeel. Chocolaty, almondy finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers who work directly with Origin Coffee Labs in Piura, Peru, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Coffee Name: Panama Hacienda La Esmeralda Geisha Natural
Blind Assessment: Richly fruity, deeply chocolaty. Dark chocolate, dried peach, honeysuckle, maple syrup, marjoram in aroma and cup. Richly sweet structure with fruit-toned acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The long, resonant finish centers around notes of dark chocolate and honeysuckle.
Notes: Produced at Hacienda La Esmeralda, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Euphora Coffee is a Taipei-based specialty coffee roaster with an active online community through which all sales are made. Visit

Coffee Name: Panama Hacienda La Esmeralda Geisha Washed
Blind Assessment: High-toned, juicy-sweet. Lemongrass, cocoa nib, magnolia, amber, bergamot in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet structure with juicy, sparkling acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. The resonant finish leads with notes of lemongrass and cocoa nib, supported by sweet magnolia.
Notes: Produced at Hacienda La Esmeralda, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed before beans are dried). Euphora Coffee is a Taipei-based specialty coffee roaster with an active online community through which all sales are made. Visit

Coffee Origin: Ka'u growing district, Big Island of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Delicately fruit-forward, richly aromatic. Lychee, tangerine, wild honey, tarragon, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Sweet, gently tart acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Integrated, long, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 8 coffee on

Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia
Blind Assessment: Richly earthy, deeply spice-toned. Graphite, pink peppercorn, guava, fresh-cut cedar, lemon verbena in aroma and cup. Crisply sweet-savory with gently bright acidity; very full, satiny mouthfeel. Pleasing savory-leaning finish centered around graphite and pink peppercorn with undertones of sweet-tart guava.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 17 coffee on

Coffee Name: Panama Finca Don Julian Geisha Washed
Blind Assessment: Brightly sweet, floral-toned. Narcissus, pink grapefruit, apricot, almond butter, bay leaf in aroma and cup. High-toned acidity; very smooth, silky mouthfeel. The resonant finish amplifies narcissus and almond.
Notes: Produced by Heakyung Kang Burneskis of Finca Don Julian, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). GK Coffee is a nano-roastery in Yilan, Taiwan, that offers both retail and wholesale coffee. For more information, visit

Blind Assessment: Richly chocolaty, boldly structured. Dark chocolate, pomegranate, fresh-cut oak, agave syrup, oregano in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart with a dry, tannic structure and gently bright acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. The harmonious finish consolidates to dark chocolate and oregano.
Notes: Produced by Patricia Perez Diaz, from trees of the Red Bourbon and Caturra varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Barrington Coffee is an artisan roaster dedicated to elite coffees, fresh delivery and roasting that foregrounds the coffee and not the roast. Visit

Coffee Name: Taiwan Nantou Yuchi Kanon Estate SL34 Natural
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-savory. Salted caramel, tamarind, hazelnut, freesia, green peppercorn in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The lingering finish leads with salted caramel and tamarind.
Notes: Produced by YuChin Kao of Kanon Estate, from trees of the SL34 variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Gediyo Yirgacheffe Burtukan Wako Natural G1
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, crisply floral. Magnolia, cashew, maple syrup, dried nectarine, myrrh in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with bright, juicy acidity; silky-smooth mouthfeel. The crisp finish highlights notes of almond and myrrh.
Notes: Produced by Burkutan Wako, from indigenous Ethiopian landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Small Eyes Café is a small, family-owned coffee shop in Yilan, Taiwan, specializing in artisanally roasted specialty coffee and homemade desserts. Visit

Blind Assessment: Berry-driven, spice-toned. Mulberry, clove, ginger blossom, oak, baking chocolate in aroma and cup. Sweetly brisk acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. The spice-toned finish leads with notes of ginger blossom and clove.
Notes: Turihamwe Turashobora is a small investor group started by seven women coffee producers who pooled their money to build their own wet mill in 2019. This coffee is produced entirely of the Bourbon variety of Arabica and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Founded in 1995 by Brooke McDonnell and Helen Russell, Equator Coffees operates retail stores in the San Francisco Bay Area and southern California and provides coffee to hundreds of wholesale accounts. Visit

Blind Assessment: Deep-toned, crisply chocolaty. Dark chocolate, dried cherry, cashew, gently scorched cedar, gardenia in aroma and cup. Richly sweet with mild acidity; viscous, syrupy mouthfeel. Very chocolaty finish with undertones of dried cherry and gardenia.
Notes: Produced by the 20 smallholding women farmers of “Woman Power Zongolica!” from the Caturra, Catuai, Sarchimor and Marsellesa varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed from the beans before they are dried). Nostalgia Coffee Roasters was founded by Taylor Fields in 2018 as a mobile café; it has since added specialty roasting, an online store, a café, and a national wholesale program featuring select fine coffees. Visit

Blind Assessment: Deep-toned, sweetly citrusy. Pomelo, cantaloupe, cocoa nib, lemon-thyme, caramel in aroma and cup. Gently bright acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to pretty notes of lemon-thyme and cantaloupe.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from selections of indigenous landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed at Tiluse Washing Station by the honey method (some fruit flesh is left on the beans during the drying process). Wonderstate Coffee, formerly Kickapoo Coffee, is an award-winning roaster based in rural Wisconsin known for its commitment to guaranteeing higher pay for farmers and operating the country’s first 100% solar-powered roastery. Visit

Blind Assessment: Round, cocoa-toned, richly bittersweet. Cocoa nib, date, maple syrup, walnut, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Softly brisk structure; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates around walnut and maple syrup in a crisp finish.
Notes: This Rugori micro-lot is produced by smallholding women farmers surrounding the Gasharu Washing Station, entirely of traditional selections of the Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Cafecita is a women-owned specialty coffee roaster based in Los Angeles that sources exclusively from sustainable women-owned coffee farms and cooperatives.

Blind Assessment: Juicy, fruit-driven. Dried apricot, rambutan, cocoa nib, magnolia, bergamot in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with bright, vibrant acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Floral finish with dried apricot undertones.
Notes: Produced by Jorge Rojas of Finca La Roca, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the honey anaerobic method, in which some of the fruit flesh is left on the beans both while they undergo fermentation in a hermetically sealed vessel, and when they are dried. Jaunt Coffee Roasters is a San Diego-based roaster and café with an extensive coffee and food menu. Visit

Blind Assessment: Tangy-sweet, richly aromatic. Tamarind, salted caramel, cedar, magnolia, lemon yogurt in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet-tart acidity; very full, creamy-smooth mouthfeel. Tart-leaning finish with ballast from caramel notes.
Notes: Produced by Edward Giraldo of Finca La Esperanza, entirely of the Typica variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic washed method, in which the fermentation step occurs in a hermetically sealed vessel before the beans are washed and dried. Jaunt Coffee Roasters is a San Diego-based roaster and café with an extensive coffee and food menu. Visit

Coffee Name: Tanama Domenico Celli Borrero Anaerobic Natural
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, balanced. Pomegranate, vanilla bean, rum barrel, lemon yogurt, honey in aroma and cup. Sweet-savory structure with brisk acidity; lightly satiny mouthfeel. Crisp, fruit-toned finish with hints of rum barrel and vanilla.
Notes: Produced by Domenico Celli Borrero at Finca Tanamá, from trees of the Typica 401, Fronton, Bourbon and Limani heirloom varieties of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which the whole fruit is fermented in an oxygen-free environment before drying. Forgotten Forest is a coffee producer and roaster in Puerto Rico dedicated to reviving production of local heirloom coffee varieties. Visit

Blind Assessment: Deeply aromatic, rich-toned. Bergamot, nectarine, cocoa nib, hazelnut butter, wisteria in aroma and cup. Sweetly spice-toned with juicy, integrated acidity; silky, viscous mouthfeel. Balanced, long, very bright finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of indigenous landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Big Shoulders Coffee is a Chicago artisan roaster that emphasizes a fresh-roasted, no-nonsense approach to fine coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Richly cocoa-toned, citrusy. Tangerine, dark chocolate, pecan, marjoram, narcissus in aroma and cup. Gently bright acidity; crisp, creamy mouthfeel. Chocolaty finish with undertones of tangerine and pecan.
Notes: Produced by Carlos and Paola Arturo Trujillo, a father-daughter team, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Big Shoulders Coffee is a Chicago artisan roaster that emphasizes a fresh-roasted, no-nonsense approach to fine coffee. Visit

Blind Assessment: Delicately fruit-forward. Dried strawberry, cherry blossom, honey, sandalwood, tangerine zest in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with balanced, fruit-toned acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Crisply berry-driven finish.
Notes: Produced by

Blind Assessment: Very sweet, fruit-driven. Honeydew melon, Froot Loops cereal, cocoa nib, orange zest, oak in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. The finish is long, sweet, and fruit-toned.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from selections of traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit) with the addition of wine yeasts in the drying process. Founded in 1994, Coffee By Design is a specialty coffee roaster in Portland, Maine that also operates three coffee shops in Portland. For more information, visit

Blind Assessment: Deep-toned, earthy-sweet. Dark chocolate, petrichor, freesia, tangerine zest, cedar in aroma and cup. Savory-leaning structure with brisk acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Chocolaty finish with undertones of sweet earthiness.
Notes: Produced by Ms. Lndayana, Ms. Dini and Ms. Murul Kemala of the Ratu Ketiara Women’s Cooperative, from trees of the Catimor and Typica varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional Sumatra washed and wet-hulled method. Nostalgia Coffee Roasters was founded by Taylor Fields in 2018 as a mobile café; it has since added specialty roasting, an online store, a café, and a national wholesale program featuring select fine coffees. Blind Assessment: Richly fruit-toned, juicy-sweet. Dried cherry, almond butter, cocoa nib, narcissus, oak in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet-tart acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Dried cherry and almond butter lead in the resonant finish.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Costa Rica and Ethiopia. Bargain Cafe is a specialty coffee roaster in Taitung, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Complex, richly fruit-toned. Lychee, dark chocolate, sandalwood, honey, wisteria in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet with juicy, balanced acidity; full, very silky mouthfeel. Long, lingering finish resonant with honey and wisteria.
Notes: Produced at Lucy Station in the Bench-Maji Zone of southern Ethiopia, entirely of the Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Small Eyes Café is a small, family-owned coffee shop in Yilan, Taiwan, specializing in artisanally roasted specialty coffee and homemade desserts. Visit

Blind Assessment: Crisply fruit-forward, gently spice-toned. Raspberry, nutmeg, walnut, amber, baking chocolate in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with gently round acidity; full, velvety mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of baking chocolate and nutmeg.
Notes: This version of the ancient Mocha-Java blend persuasively combines a traditionally processed, wet-hulled Sumatra Ketiara in place of the original Java and replaces the Yemen Mocha with

Coffee Name: Colombia Huila El Vergel Yellow Fruit Anaerobic
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-savory, gently lactic. Pineapple yogurt, lemon balm, baking chocolate, sandalwood, marjoram in aroma and cup. Sweet-savory structure with tangy acidity; soft, satiny mouthfeel. Fruit- and cocoa-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by Marta Bayter and her sons, Shady and Elias, of Vergel Estate, from trees of the Yellow Caturra and Colombia varieties of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which the coffee is fermented in the whole fruit with limited access to oxygen before drying. Kafe Coffee Roastery is a specialty roaster based in Zhubei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet, gently floral. Apricot, magnolia, baking chocolate, lemon zest, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Brisk acidity; lightly silky mouthfeel. The wood-framed finish is supported by notes of lemon zest and magnolia.
Notes: Produced at

Coffee Name: Colombia Finca El Paraíso Geisha Sake
Blind Assessment: Exuberantly aromatic, rich, very complex. Bergamot, Concord grape, ginger blossom, pistachio, lychee in aroma and cup. Juicy-bright, exceptionally high-toned acidity; lush, silky mouthfeel. Rich, pungent, crisply sweet finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 10 coffee on

Blind Assessment: Brightly sweet-tart, vibrant. Berry melange, cocoa nib, star jasmine, agave syrup, cedar in aroma and cup. Juicy, high-toned acidity; crisp, very syrupy mouthfeel. The sweet-toned finish centers around notes of raspberry and cocoa nib with undertones of star jasmine.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 26 coffee on

Blind Assessment: Sweetly tart, richly savory. Magnolia, pink grapefruit zest, ripe blackberry, dark chocolate, toffee in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet, complex structure with high-toned acidity; plush, very syrupy mouthfeel. Magnolia and blackberry notes lead in the long, resonant finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of the Gachatha Farmers’ Cooperative Society from trees of the SL28, SL34 and Ruiru 11 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit

Coffee Origin: Sabanilla de Alajuela, Central Valley, Costa Rica
Blind Assessment: Gently fruit-forward, balanced. Black cherry, tea rose, walnut, baking chocolate, cedar in aroma and cup. Bold, brisk acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of black cherry and cedar.
Notes: Produced by Francisca and Oscar Chacon of Finca Las Lajas, from trees of the Caturra and Catuai varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Conscious Cup Coffee Roasters is an independent and family-owned and -operated cafe and coffee roaster specializing in socially and environmentally sustainable coffees. Visit

Coffee Name: Kenya Nyeri Gatuya Factory AA Top
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-savory, juicy-bright. Dark chocolate, hop flowers, apricot, tangerine zest, cedar in aroma and cup. High-toned, lively acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthfeel. The resonant finish sustains its flavor-saturated structure far into the long.
Notes: Produced at the Gatuya factory, from trees of the SL28 and SL34 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Richly chocolaty, gently fruit-forward. Dark chocolate, dried plum, rhododendron, roasted almond, fresh-cut fir in aroma and small cup. Very syrupy mouthfeel; crisply chocolaty, wood-framed finish. In cappuccino-scaled milk, attractive notes of dark chocolate and dried plum dominate.
Notes: A blend of various coffees from South America, decaffeinated in Colombia using ethyl acetate, a solvent derived from sugar cane. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit

Coffee Name: Costa Rica Tarrazu Double Anaerobic Washed
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-tart, complex. Pineapple kefir, lilac, dark chocolate, amber, honey in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy acidity; satiny, viscous mouthfeel. A long finish centers around pineapple, amber and honey notes.
Notes: Produced at Finca La Loma, entirely of the Caturra variety of Arabica, and processed by the double-anaerobic washed method, in which the fermentation step occurs in a hermetically sealed vessel before the beans are washed and dried. Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Name: Ethiopia Natural Bench Maji Lucy Station Gesha
Blind Assessment: Richly aromatic, fruit-forward. Mulberry, almond nougat, lemon verbena, cocoa nib, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with juicy acidity; lightly satiny mouthfeel. Crisp, fruity, cocoa-toned finish.
Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It is processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit

Coffee Origin: Pegasing, Takengon, Aceh Province, Sumatra, Indonesia
Blind Assessment: Sweetly spice-toned. Nutmeg, baking chocolate, cranberry, oak, rhododendron in aroma and cup. Pert acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Notes of baking chocolate, cranberry and oak lead in a resonant finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the Gayo 1, Gayo 2, Catimor and Abyssinia varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Conscious Cup Coffee Roasters is an independent and family-owned and -operated cafe and coffee roaster specializing in socially and environmentally sustainable coffees. Visit

Blind Assessment: Crisply cocoa-toned, quietly fruit-forward. Cocoa powder, mulberry, caramel, fir, orange zest in aroma and cup. Gentle acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned finish with notes of caramel and fir.
Notes: Produced by Mirna Lizeth Dominguez Marquez of Finca El Colobri, from trees of the Lempira and Parainema varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Conscious Cup Coffee Roasters is an independent and family-owned and -operated cafe and coffee roaster specializing in socially and environmentally sustainable coffees. Visit

Blind Assessment: Understated, crisply sweet. Walnut, cocoa powder, maple syrup, pear, wine barrel in aroma and cup. Softly brisk acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates around maple syrup and walnut notes in the gently drying finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers of the Duwancho Cooperative, from trees of the 74158 Ethiopia variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly roast-rounded, chocolaty. Dark chocolate, caramel, gently scorched oak, almond, gardenia in aroma and small cup. Crisp, velvety mouthfeel; gently drying, chocolaty finish. In three parts milk, gardenia and dark chocolate notes harmonize nicely.
Notes: A blend of two Ethiopia coffees, a Guji and a Yirgacheffe, roasted for espresso applications. Philipsburg Coffee Roasters is a specialty roaster based in Montana’s Flint Creek Valley that focuses on four to five seasonally rotating coffees at a time. Visit

Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet, balanced. Baking chocolate, plum, magnolia, cedar, almond in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with brisk acidity; velvety-smooth mouthfeel. The gently drying finish consolidates to almond and cedar.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the Ethiopia 74110 variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Lee Dong Coffee is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taichung, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Origin: Arbegona Woreda, Bursa Kebele, Sidama Region, Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Quietly sweet-tart. Pomegranate, fir, caramel, freesia, almond in aroma and cup. Brisk acidity; lightly satiny mouthfeel. Sweetly wood-framed finish supported by suggestions of freesia.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the 74158 Ethiopia variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Name: Brasil Ipanema Premier Cru BLUE A50 Red Anaerobic Natural
Coffee Origin: Serra da Mantiqueira-Fazenda Rio Verde, Sul De Minas, Brazil
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-savory. Date, ginkgo, vanilla yogurt, fir, saltwater taffy in aroma and cup. Tart-leaning acidity; velvety mouthfeel. Gently drying, tart finish.
Notes: Produced by Ipanema Coffees at Fazenda Rio Verde, entirely of the Red Acaia variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which the coffee is fermented in the whole fruit with limited access to oxygen before drying. Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Wildly expressive, richly compelling. Blackberry jam, sweet cream, frankincense, honeysuckle, dried pineapple in aroma and cup. Wine-like, very juicy, integrated acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Very long, very complex finish that leads with notes of wild blackberry and frankincense.
Notes: This remarkable coffee was selected as the No. 1 coffee on

Coffee Name: Costa Rica Las Lajas SL28 Natural
Coffee Origin: Sabanilla de Alajuela, Central Valley, Costa Rica
Blind Assessment: Floral-toned, rich with fruit. Star jasmine, passionfruit, cocoa nib, wild honey, cedar in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet acidity; very syrupy mouthfeel. Long, lingering, integrated finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 19 coffee on

Coffee Origin: Agaro Gera, Jimma Zone, Oromia State, Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Delicate, complex, high-toned. Bergamot, plumeria, lemongrass, cocoa nib, dried apricot in aroma and cup. Juicy, balanced acidity; exceptionally silky mouthfeel. The finish fulfills the promise of the cup, carrying forward all of the flavor and aroma notes.
Notes: Produced by the Nano Genji cooperative in Ethiopia’s Jimma Zone. Ethiopia coffees like this one are produced largely from selections of local, indigenous varieties of Arabica. Processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Certified organic. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit

Blind Assessment: Raspberry jam, toffee, dark chocolate, lilac, hint of teriyaki sauce in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with brisk acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Savory-leaning in the resonant finish with notes of teriyaki sauce supported by dark chocolate.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez of Finca El Paraíso entirely of the rare Pink Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by a complexly detailed version of the double-anaerobic method (sealed-tank fermentation of the whole fruit with the addition of brewer’s yeast, removal of skin and pulp, and a second fermentation of the beans shut in the tank with the removed skin and pulp). Additional processing nuance includes a thermal shock wash (soaking the whole fruit in hot water for 30 seconds, then cold water for 30 seconds) to reduce astringency. Green Stone Coffee is a woman-owned artisan roastery in Taipei, Taiwan founded in 2016 and specializing in sourcing distinctive coffees that express their individual terroirs. Visit

Blind Assessment: Deeply chocolaty, richly floral. Dark chocolate, gently scorched oak, gardenia, lily, raspberry in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; full, creamy mouthfeel. Chocolaty finish with undertones of smoky oak and gardenia.
Notes: Produced at Aquiares Estate, entirely of the Centroamericano variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). David's Nose is a specialty coffee roaster based in Taipei, Taiwan whose founder studied agronomy and has a deep interest in crop quality. For more information, visit

Blind Assessment: Delicately fruit-toned, wood-framed. Plum, fresh-cut cedar, lily, cocoa powder, orange zest in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with brisk acidity; delicate, silky mouthfeel. Cocoa nib and orange zest carry the crisp, quiet finish.
Notes: Produced at Cerro San Luis Micromill, from trees of the Red Bourbon, Orange Bourbon, SL28, Catuai, Villa Sarchi and Maragogype varieties of Arabica, and processed by the white honey method, in which a small amount of fruit flesh is left on the bean during drying. Founded in 2007 and named after the white rhino, which is both rare and social, White Rhino Coffee is based in Dallas, Texas and currently has nine coffee shops in addition to its roastery. Visit

Coffee Origin: Pegasing, Takengon, Aceh Province, Sumatra, Indonesia
Blind Assessment: Crisply chocolaty, sweetly earth-toned. Baking chocolate, nutmeg, cane sugar, raisin, fir in aroma and cup. Brisk acidity; velvety mouthfeel. The gently drying finish consolidates to notes of nutmeg and fir.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the Gayo 1, Gayo 2, Catimor and Abyssinia varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Founded in 2007 and named after the white rhino, which is both rare and social, White Rhino Coffee is based in Dallas, Texas, and currently has nine coffee shops in addition to its roastery. Visit

Blind Assessment: Complex, richly floral-toned. Lavender, cocoa nib, starfruit, ginseng, honey in aroma and cup. Bright balanced acidity; vibrant, silky mouthfeel. The long, resonant finish, sweet and multi-layered, fulfills the promise of the cup.
Notes: Produced by Wilder Lasso of Bella Alejandría Farm entirely of the Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed anaerobic method, in which the fermentation step occurs in a hermetically sealed vessel before the beans are washed and dried. Mostra Coffee is a women-, minority-, veteran-, and immigrant-owned micro-roaster based in north county San Diego. For more information, visit

Blind Assessment: Sweetly tart, delicately complex. White peach, honeysuckle, tangerine zest, caramel, elm in aroma and cup. Apple-like acidity; vibrant, silky mouthfeel. Quiet but long, harmonious finish.
Notes: Produced on HWC Coffee Estate, entirely of the celebrated Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). HWC Roasters is a specialty coffee roaster based in Taichung, Taiwan. For more information, visit

Coffee Origin: Sitio Pluto, Balutakay, Managa, Davao del Sur, Philippines
Blind Assessment: Sweetly nut-toned, richly bittersweet. Almond toffee, sarsparilla, lemon verbena, cane sugar, cedar in aroma and cup. Brisk acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of cedar and lemon verbena.
Notes: Produced by Rosemarie Rupecio of the

Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-savory. Cocoa powder, cherry liqueur, pine, marjoram, brown sugar in aroma and cup. Bittersweet with brisk acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Wood-framed finish with hints of cocoa powder and cherry liqueur.
Notes: Produced on HWC Coffee Estate, entirely of the celebrated Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). HWC Roasters is a specialty coffee roaster based in Taichung, Taiwan. For more information, visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Crisply chocolaty, sweetly nut-toned. Baking chocolate, cashew butter, date, gently scorched cedar, a hint of vanilla in aroma and small cup. Velvety mouthfeel; nutty finish with undertones of lightly scorched cedar. Smoky aromatic wood notes play well with chocolate in three parts milk.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Colombia, Ethiopia and Brazil, roasted for espresso applications. HWC Roasters is a specialty coffee roaster based in Taichung, Taiwan. For more information, visit

Coffee Name: Colombia Fruit Maceration Series Lulo Bear
Blind Assessment: Confidently fruit-forward. Pineapple yogurt, Concord grape, freesia, marjoram, chocolate syrup in aroma and cup. Crisp, apple-like acidity; full, very syrupy mouthfeel. In the finish, lactic, yogurty tang supported by fruit notes.
Notes: Produced by Jairo Arcilo, entirely of the Castillo variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic method, in which the coffee is fermented in the whole fruit with limited access to oxygen before drying. With this coffee, both wine yeasts and macerated lulo fruit were added to the ferment tank. Founded in 2013, modcup coffee focuses on fresh roasting and distinctive natural-processed coffees. Visit

Blind Assessment: Delicately floral, richly aromatic. Wisteria, apricot, honey, amber, black tea in aroma and cup. Gently bright acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Finish centers around notes of amber and honey.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed before beans are dried). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Coffee Name: Colombia Wilton Benitez Double Anaerobic Thermal Shock Yellow Gesha
Blind Assessment: Richly aromatic, tropical. Passionfruit, ginger, star jasmine, fresh-cut oak, cherry liqueur in aroma and cup. Fruity acidity; viscous, creamy mouthfeel. The spice-toned finish centers around on notes of ginger and cherry liqueur.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez of La Macarena Farm, entirely of the Yellow Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by a complexly detailed version of the double-anaerobic method (sealed-tank fermentation of the whole fruit with the addition of brewer’s yeast, removal of skin and pulp, and a second fermentation of the beans shut in the tank with the removed skin and pulp). Additional processing nuance includes a thermal shock wash (soaking the whole fruit in hot water for 30 seconds, then cold water for 30 seconds) to reduce astringency. Founded in 2013, modcup coffee focuses on fresh roasting and distinctive natural-processed coffees. Visit

Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Richly aromatic, deeply savory. Lilac, dark chocolate, goji berry, pomelo, shiitake mushroom in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart-savory structure with bright acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The flavor-laden finish leads with goji berry in the short, rounding to deep chocolate and shiitake notes in the long.
Notes: Guji is nestled next to Ethiopia's better-known Yirgacheffe and Sidamo growing regions. This is a “natural” or dry-processed coffee (dried in the whole fruit). VERYTIME is a specialty nano-roaster based in Taoyuan, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, gently tart. Wisteria, pomegranate, fresh-cut fir, brown sugar, grapefruit zest in aroma and cup. Brisk acidity; very full, satiny mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of fir, brown sugar and grapefruit zest.
Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It is processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). VERYTIME is a specialty nano-roaster based in Taoyuan, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Richly chocolaty, deep-toned. Dark chocolate, graham cracker, almond butter, cedar, tangerine zest in aroma and small cup. Very smooth, viscous mouthfeel; crisply chocolaty, nut-toned finish. In cappuccino-scaled milk, dark chocolate is further amplified to an almost dessert-like intensity.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the Castillo and Caturra varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed before beans are dried). Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features selections from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit

Coffee Name: Costa Rica Finca Sabana Redonda SL28
Coffee Origin: Poas Volcano, Alajuela Province, Costa Rica
Est. Price: $32.00/boxed set (125 grams of this coffee plus 125 grams of an anaerobic-processed coffee from the same farm)
Blind Assessment: Fruit-toned, richly sweet-tart. Pomegranate, lemon balm, hazelnut, cocoa nib, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Crisp, juicy acidity, plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Long, resonant finish leads with notes of pomegranate and cocoa nib.
Notes: Produced by Francisco Cubillo and Oscar Chacon, entirely of the SL28 variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural aerobic method (fermented in the whole fruit in tanks with oxygen exposure), followed by two drying stages. Torque Coffee has a unique business model that promises 20 percent of the retail value of each coffee to its producer. Visit

Coffee Name: Panama Hacienda La Esmeralda Diamond Mountain Catuai Washed
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-tart, citrusy. Lime zest, cocoa nib, jasmine, plum, cedar in aroma and cup. Balanced, vibrant acidity; satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned citrus notes lead in the long finish.
Notes: Produced at Hacienda La Esmeralda, entirely of the Catuai variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed before beans are dried). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit

Blind Assessment: Brightly sweet, vibrant. Nectarine, hazelnut, grapefruit zest, fresh-cut oak, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Juicy acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of hazelnut and grapefruit.
Notes: Produced by Arturo Aguirre of El Injerto Farm, from trees of the Caturra and Bourbon varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed before beans are dried). Ba Yang Coffee is a specialty roaster based in New Taipei City, Taiwan.  Visit

Blind Assessment: Brewed in a Toddy Small-Batch Artisan Brewer and evaluated chilled. Balanced, sweetly bright. Honeysuckle, tamarind, mulberry, cedar, orange zest in aroma and cup. Lightly plump, satiny mouthfeel; crisply sweet finish. With milk, complex and resonant, with honeysuckle and mulberry highlights.
Notes: A whole-bean coffee sourced and roasted for cold brewing at home. For this review brewed at the

Coffee Name: Yemen Al Kawlah Special Reserve Natural
Blind Assessment: Richly fruit-toned, chocolaty. Dark chocolate, red currant, tangerine zest, oak, honey in aroma and cup. Winy acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Chocolaty, citrus-driven finish, invitingly bittersweet.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 30 coffee on

Coffee Origin: Holualoa, Kona, Big Island of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Richly nut-toned, very sweet. Toffee, hazelnut, magnolia, green grape, marjoram in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy-sweet acidity; lively, viscous mouthfeel. Long, resonant finish that harmoniously carries forward all the notes from the cup.
Notes: Produced at Noelani Farm, entirely of the K7 variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit

Coffee Origin: El Chaco Canton, Parroquia Santa Rosa, Napo Province, Ecuador
Blind Assessment: Richly aromatic, floral, spice-toned. Orange blossom, dark chocolate, agave, cedar, cardamom in aroma and cup. Sweetly savory structure with high-toned acidity; viscous, full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to orange blossom and cardamom.
Notes: Produced by Leopoldo Andrade of La Josefina Estate, entirely of the Sidra variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Magnolia Coffee is a Charlotte-based specialty roaster whose mission is to use sustainably sourced coffees to make a difference in the lives of coffee workers and to foster a socially conscious community with cause-supporting coffees. Visit

Coffee Origin: Bonga Forest, Keficho-Shekicho Zone, southwest Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Deeply sweet, fruit-forward. Bing cherry, dark chocolate, marshmallow, cashew, lime zest in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with bright, juicy acidity; full, creamy-smooth mouthfeel. The cleanly fruit-toned finish shows undertones of cashew and dark chocolate.
